The Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is one of the greatest action adventure games to grace PlayStation.

And I stress, PlayStation.

Do not misunderstand me, regardless of what platform you enjoy it on, Soul Reaver still has incredible characters, story, and presentation that remains unmatched in the world of Gothic Horror. It controls and plays wonderfully, borrowing elements from The Legend of Zelda with back-tracking and exploration more akin to Super Metroid, or the later Castlevania games. It is more than apt that fans have continued to follow the Nosgoth universe, as well as the rest of the Legacy of Kain series, well beyond Soul Reaver's initial release.

However, with that all said, Soul Reaver on PC does not hold up.

This port loses much of the seamless nature of Soul Reaver's design, and as a result, the game's identity suffers as a result of that. The audio is hit the hardest with obvious fades implemented on audio tracks rather than continuously looping and blending naturally between different areas of the map. Outside of that though, sound just randomly breaks, with odd popping and crackling and even some of the effects playing at a much delayed rate... Or not at all even.

To be fair, it is otherwise a dramatic improvement over the PlayStation version, with graphical settings that will scale however far you want. Using mods as well, you can introduce higher frame-rates and potentially get better looking textures and models as well, although these often come with their own quirks and create new problems as well.

I don't want to disparage anyone from wanting to play Soul Reaver, honestly, go out and enjoy it but do so on hardware that can (i.e. Playstation) if you find the option to. The PC version was palatable back in 1998 because it ran appropriately for hardware of the day, but unfortunately time hasn't been as kind to what now feels like a slapdash conversion of something that deserves so, so much better.

Fingers crossed this does eventually get the Nightdive Studios treatment because it totally needs (and deserves) it.

TL;DR:  Fantastic dialog, good worldbuilding, and lots of potential, but it hasn't aged well.  Unstable, camera sucks, puzzles don't take advantage of the game's mechanics, and combat isn't worth the trouble.

The Soul Reaver series was highly recommended to me once upon a time, though it took me almost 10 years to actually get around to beating one.  It's got some great things going for it, but ultimately I finished it more for the sake of completion than because I actually enjoyed it.  For starters, even getting it to run can be difficult, and even once that's solved, the game is hardly stable, especially for audio.  Beyond technical issues, the gameplay also doesn't hold up well.  As I see it, there are 3 main facets of the gameplay - platforming, puzzles, and combat - each with their own problems:

Platforming:  This sucks mainly because of the camera.  This game was clearly meant to be played on a console, and it shows.  There's no mouse look in vanilla, and even mods can only partially fix that.  Moving in some places automatically moves the camera, which can be nice but only when you're doing exactly what the auto movement is meant to help with - otherwise it's just disorienting.  Tapping a key to make fine camera adjustments instead recenters the camera, which can be frustrating when you're trying to line up a precise jump on a time crunch.  Looking up and down is slow and prevents you from doing most other actions.  With no map, only symbols identifying each Gate, and the camera being what it is, just trying to remember where you've been, let alone finding new areas or secrets, can be a pain.

Puzzles:  Here, the Silent Cathedral is an example of the worst issues.  With little context for what I'm doing and why, some puzzles are solved just by exploring the level and interacting with every "thing that I can interact with" until something desirable happens.  You can only Shift to the Physical realm in fixed spots, so puzzles involving Shifting are usually glaringly obvious.  Worst of all are the block puzzles.  Dear god are there a LOT of block puzzles.  Once you learn that you can stack and rotate blocks, solving the puzzles takes little headwork but a lot of time.

Combat:  Combat straight-up sucks.  You lose the Soul Reaver upon taking any damage, and after that are forced to rely on your environment to actually kill enemies.  This is mostly fine if spears or torches are available, but my soul dies every time I'm forced to rely on throwing enemies to kill them.  The camera issues make this a difficult affair, and your throw has no aim assist - miss by a few degrees, stand too close or too far from the spike, and the enemy will bounce harmlessly off.  Glyphs are more significant for the optional puzzles required to gain them than for actually using them; they're not that useful, the menu is clunky, and overall they feel like an afterthought (for the record, I found all of them, including the Fire Reaver).  Enemies infinitely (and rapidly) respawn, and you're liable to lose more health by fighting them than you'd gain by consuming their souls, so you're better off completely bypassing enemies unless combat is the only option.

To end on a positive note, here are some things I liked about Soul Reaver:  The dialog and voice acting are PHENOMENAL.  I could listen to Kain and Raziel exchange verbal spears all day long.  The lore is also quite interesting, and my exploration rewarding me with just a little bit more information about this world was what kept me going through the dull parts.  The difference in physics and abilities between the Physical and Spectral realm is the most interesting part of the gameplay, and if I was to remake Soul Reaver, that's what I would focus on - rather than block puzzles.

Overall, I can't really recommend playing it.  There's a TON of potential here, and I'd love to see a modern re-imagining that can take advantage of it, but as-is, it's aged poorly.

TLDR i believe what i am about to write is actually important, one of the most important opinions i have on the games medium as a whole, as well as my love and reverence for a title that i have ZERO nostalgia for, a game that won me over purely by being one of the BEST things I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED!

Disclaimer, skip this next part if you think you can get a'hold of this game, already own it, or simply want the actual review.

I own this game and its sequels on steam, thank god i got in before the delisting. I have also been playing this on my steamdeck via retrodeck, grabbed a copy of the og ps1 disk second hand, so the following GLOWING PRAISE better be seen as such, especially since its not available on this platform right now. For now, i recommend getting it however you can, because its nearing abandon ware territory for the pc platform, I don't think its even available in the back catalog of streamables on the playstation plus service.

I digress. I did not come here to bemoan the issues of modern preservation.. (BUT ITS IMPORTANT!) 
The gameplay of soul reaver, is that of the other side of the coin from the legend of zelda series, strip away the copious utility items, but retain the complexity of the puzzles and combat, streamline it, but make it more brutal, improvised environmental hazards, and weapons that you pluck from the corpses of your enemies. A puzzle dynamic of intentionally experiencing death in order to solve problems in a spirit world. Devouring the souls of the conquered to maintain your physical form. Thats all incredibly bad ass! IT ALL HOLDS UP. This review is in 2023, im turning 32. I DID NOT GROW UP WITH THESE F%#%ing GAMES! But what is it really that is the glue that holds this special experience together? 

There are some genres and genre staples that have been through the ringer. VAMPIRES, and (3D ACTION PLATFORMERS) have both seen levels of over-saturation that have influenced peoples opinions of them quite permanently. Some of us never lost the love, but i dont begrudge you if you have. Soul Reaver, and its sequels and the game that spawned it, Legacy of Kain Blood omen, are the peak of their respected tropes and categories. The world of Nosgoth is one i have never seen before or since, even though it has elements of vampire lore, dark fantasy, and lovecraftian horror, it also heavily relies on a foundation of philosophy and prose, you are watching and involved in a story that spans the course of an entire peoples rise and fall, the dark fate of an individual being a catalyst for great change, and the machinations of antagonists that represent a mirror to the protagonists own ignorance, and the hubris of that antagonist being a necessary foil to a plot that spans the history of the entire setting, he himself once a fallen hero now deified as the highest evolution of vampire and has seen time unravel from his actions. The various perspectives and dialogues you encounter will move you... In a game that leans in to horror as set dressing, this should remind you of the most beautiful works of horror fiction that came right from the very start, Frankenstein's Monster, and Dracula, two works of horror fiction that have a romantic soft underbelly that makes us remember them long after they were consumed by their first audiences.

Soul reaver, and its sequels is an exquisite piece of culture that we are losing our grip on, probably because it didn't have the preservation appeal that many of the other landmarks of its era did. Not for lack of love, but very likely for greed or incompetence. You owe it to yourself to start here, stick with it, and fall in love. IF you are curious about the original blood omen game and think you can hang in that retro experience, it is equal but different. A review for another time.

A Timeless Classic that Still Resonates

Rating: ★★★★★

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is a game that many of us hold close to our hearts. It's a title that, even after many years, still holds a certain magic, a sense of nostalgia that transports us back to simpler times. It's more than just a game, it's a piece of our gaming history, and revisiting it always feels like coming home.

Soul Reaver's dark, gothic atmosphere and compelling narrative were groundbreaking at the time of its release. The tale of Raziel, betrayed and cast into the abyss by his master Kain, only to be reborn as a wraith, was a narrative feast. The game's voice acting, particularly Michael Bell as Raziel and Simon Templeman as Kain, gave life to this saga of vengeance in a way few games of the era could match.

The game's unique mechanic of shifting between the spectral and material plane was not only innovative but also intrinsically linked to both the narrative and puzzle-solving. This added a layer of depth to the gameplay, requiring you to think about the environment in two different states and utilize this mechanic to navigate and solve the game's many intricate puzzles.

The combat system, which focused on the use of improvised weapons and the environment, added a unique twist to the action-adventure formula. Dispatching your vampiric brethren by impalement, immolation, or exposure to sunlight never got old.

Revisiting the world of Nosgoth, with its beautifully designed, gothic landscapes and structures, even today, is an exercise in nostalgia. The game's visual style, sound design, and score by Kurt Harland contributed to the creation of a darkly atmospheric world that still resonates with players to this day.

Yes, Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver may show its age in some aspects. Its graphics, while revolutionary at the time, may seem dated to some players today. Yet, it's important to remember that Soul Reaver was a product of its time and marked a significant milestone in the evolution of narrative-focused games.

In conclusion, Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver remains a beloved classic. It's a game that dared to push the boundaries of storytelling, with its deep narrative, complex characters, and innovative gameplay mechanics. For many of us, it's more than just a game, it's a cherished piece of our personal gaming history, a testament to the timeless appeal of a well-crafted narrative and compelling gameplay.

In 1997, the game Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain was released, which started the dark fantasy vampire saga. I myself only got to it for the first time with the title Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver, which takes place in the distant future. I originally wanted to do a little flashback on the stream, but the game completely absorbed me and I finished it again. Even when I was in elementary school, I was completely absorbed by this world and the Soul Reaver game became my heart.

Not even Discord's Nitro Boost would be enough to describe the entire story of this saga, because it is so long and connected. Soul Reaver takes place in the time when Kain (the main character from the first part) was the ruler of all the vampire clans in Nosgoth. For centuries vampires had evolved, but it was unheard of to have the audacity to evolve ahead of their master. This is what the main protagonist of this game, Raziel, did. As the first vampire grew wings. Naturally, Kain didn't like this, so he ripped Raziel's bones out of them. Furthermore, for the betrayal that Raziel committed, Kain ordered him thrown into the abyss.

This is where the game begins. At the bottom of the abyss, Raziel is saved by the Elder God. He offers Raziel a chance to take revenge. However, it is not an altruistic being. The Elder God pursues Raziel's mission as well as his own interests.

The whole saga is based on the *action-adventure* genre with lots of puzzles and riddles that you have to solve along the way. A dark atmosphere underlines the story of this vampire saga.

Games are currently not available for purchase on Steam. There is speculation about a remaster or even a remake.

My rating: 9.2/10

Soul Reaver is one of my all-time favorite games, the story and especially the voice acting are both top notch. The game play is a lot like tomb raider, but with hand to hand combat, optional spells, dodging, flying/ gliding and sucking out and consuming the souls of your enemies ;P. The world is huge and it get's doubled by being able to phase into the spirit realm. I remember thinking it was such a cool dynamic having death be merely phasing into the spirit realm where you get a chance to gain your health back and get right back into the fight. It allowed me to really get into the game without the boring repetition of traversing back through levels ad nauseum to reach the tough spots over and over again. Add that to a Metroid style world-access system wherein unlocking new abilities gains you access to new areas from those you've already conquered (even optional areas for some of the spells and upgrades) and you have an awe inspiring experience that beats anything today hands down.  If I had any criticisms it would be that the combat was too easy, enemies are not dangerous, just annoying obstacles, which makes sense as you are essentially in a predator/ prey relationship with them (and they aint the one's earning a meal), but it would have been nice to have difficulty modes that were selectable to give the game more spice. 
  The port is janky and broken, and the lack of controller support really stinks. but I hope folks are wrong and that Square Enix will incorporate some patches, polish it up a little,  and then re-post this game. It is an excellent title that deserves not to be forgotten. A complete re-skin (like FF10 received) would be beyond great. I would gladly pay full price to re-experience this game with modern graphics (hint hint).

So, uhh, I just finished my first playthrough of this game, and I must say that my experience was lukewarm, partially due to my expecations for it being too high.

The story, characters, music, voice acting and settings were all top-notch though, and I got really immersed in the gothic atmosphere. But that’s about it. Let’s go over some things at the top of my head:

- The (environmental) combat: There’s almost no point in fighting anything, as the combat is tedious and mashy and the enemies are simple obstacles you can run past.
- The camera, and precision of movement: These are mostly fine, but I found myself falling and getting mildly frustrated a few times through my playthrough due to this.
- BLOCK PUZZLES. Most of the puzzles are slow, tedious moving-block puzzles where you can easily see the solution from miles away.
- The world and the world map: It’s really confusing and easy to get lost. Had to spend some time wandering back and fourth across environments I had already explored before I could get properly situated. It wasn’t fun to do, but I slowly got a better idea of where to go when the announcer dude gave me hints on where I should’ve gone.
- Bosses: They’re cool aesthetically, but they’re very easy and quite lame to battle.
- Character motivation and ending: I’m 80% sure it’s me just not paying enough attention to, or simply forgetting  the dialog said in the game, but I was left wondering what my character’s motivation was to be in certain areas. And dat cliff-hanger ending did not wrap anything up in a satisfying manner.

When I reflect back on my time in the game, most of it was spent holding forwards running through large, empty environments, running past enemies, and groaning whenever I had to fight enemies are switch to ghost form to phase through some barrier. There just weren’t really that many interesting moment-to-moment decisions to be made.

Am I glad I played it? And am I being too negative, and not focusing on the high points of the game because mommy didn’t give me my chicken tendies? Yes, kinda.

Hopefully the 3 other Legacy of Kain games in my library fare better.

[h1]“People assume that time is a strict progression from cause to effect, but actually from a non-linear, non-subjective viewpoint, it's more like a big ball of wibbly-wobbly, timey-wimey... stuff.”
[i]~The Doctor[/i][/h1]

At the end of the summer [b]1997[/b], [b]Crystal Dynamics[/b] released what quickly became one of my most favorite video games ever – [b]Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain[/b]. On paper, it wasn't anything special. What we had there was a regular [b]2D Zelda[/b] clone. With vampires. And even though both [b]PC[/b] and [b]PlayStation[/b] (despite the fact that [b]PlayStation[/b] version was the original one and didn't have [b]FPS[/b] lock, [b]PC[/b] port was better due to the fact that there were no annoying loading times) users clearly didn't have many of such games, the clone was still a clone. But there were three things about [b]Blood Omen[/b] that instantly made it to stand out. First – the game had perfect design. [b]Scott Collie[/b]'s signature art style from [b]Silicon Knights[/b]' (even though [b]Crystal Dynamics[/b] used to make their own games, this one was developed externally by [b]Knights[/b]) previous games like [b]Fantasy Empires[/b] and [b]Dark Legions[/b] met dark fantasy, inspired by the cover of [b]Ken Follett[/b]'s [b]The Pillars of the Earth[/b] and the result was breathtaking. It was dark, it was stylish and... it had vampires.

Talking about vampires. It was the second thing about the game. Not only playing as a “bad” guy was cool, the game actually allowed us to drink blood to restore health, while the vampiric abilities? Those were pure joy. Exploring the world in the wolf form, quick traveling as a bat, walking through the closed doors in a form of a mist... Awesome stuff. You know how it is about [b]Zelda[/b] games. You beat the dungeon, you get the new tool, you use that tool to unlock the new territories for exploration. The original [b]S. Miyahon[/b]'s formula was perfect, but with some juicy vampiric abilities? It began to shine especially bright and even though [b]Blood Omen[/b] was way, [i]way[/i] slower than [b]Zelda[/b], it instantly won everybody's heart by its presentation. Finally, the third thing about [b]Blood Omen[/b] was... voice acting. Nowadays, people take [b]AAA[/b] acting for granted. While it wasn't always like that. Never before [b]Blood Omen[/b] did I hear such a great acting in video game and up to this day? I still consider [b]Simon Templeman[/b] as [b]Kain[/b] and [b]Tony Jay[/b] as a necromancer [b]Mortanius[/b] among the very best examples of voice acting in video games. The official translations weren't that lucky. Despite the fact that [b]Kain[/b] in [b]Japanese[/b] version was played by [b]Inoue Kazuhiko[/b] ([b]Nyanko[/b]-sensei in [b]Natsume Yuujinchou[/b]), Japanese dub wasn't really that good, while German and French versions were complete disasters. But the original English version? Perfection.

OK, you've got the idea that [b]Blood Omen[/b] was a good game. Presentation was great, having a [b]Zelda[/b] for [b]PC[/b] and [b]PS1[/b] was cool and naturally, [b]Crystal Dynamics[/b] wanted a sequel. The problem is... it was unclear who owned the name. [b]Silicon Knights[/b] loved their game, and were afraid to lose the rights. They even added an extra credits screen to make it absolutely clear that [b]Blood Omen[/b] was their creation. Despite that, [b]Crystal Dynamics[/b] decided to fight for the promising franchise and made it clear that they were ready to go to the court. [b]Knights[/b] weren't ready for that and as the result, it was decided that [b]CD[/b] will keep the franchise, but will credit [b]Knights[/b] in every new game. In other words, [b]CD[/b] got all the rights for [b]Kain[/b] series and were free to make new games. But guess what? In [b]1998[/b] they've got acquired by [b]Eidos Interactive[/b]. You know, the guys who were making tons of money from their new series – [b]Tomb Raider[/b] (created by [b]CORE Design[/b]). Naturally, you can easily guess the most common complaint about sequel to [b]Blood Omen[/b]. Quite a lot of the old fans claimed that... [b]Eidos[/b] forced [b]CD[/b] to turn [b]Legacy of Kain[/b] into... the [b]Tomb Raider[/b]. Which isn't really true. At least, not entirely.

See, while the original [b]LoK[/b] tried to copy the early [b]Zelda[/b] games, the sequel decided to do the [b]Ocarina of Time[/b] thing instead. In other words, even though the advanced graphics in fully [b]3D[/b] environment did remind people about [b]Tomb Raider[/b], it was still [b]Zelda[/b]. Only this time it was fully [b]3D[/b] [b]Zelda[/b] from [b]Nintendo 64[/b]. And like with the first game, the sequel did things with a lot of imagination and style. First of all, our character from the first game is actually a main villain now. [b]Soul Reaver[/b] followed the bad ending from [b]Blood Omen[/b] and let us play as the new guy – [b]Raziel[/b], one of the [b]Kain[/b]'s lieutenants who surpassed his master and was sentenced to death. Naturally, he survived and now it was his turn to take the revenge. Sounds simple, but the story actually have quite a lot of twists. Also, what we have here is just the beginning of [b]Raziel[/b]'s saga (the game ends with the cliffhanger), so... a lot more was coming.

[i]Anyway[/i], like I said, what we have here is [b]OoT[/b]. Only, unlike [b]Link[/b], [b]Raziel[/b] will switch not  between different times but between the material realm and so-called spectral realm, in which he'll have different powers. Also, the spectral realm will alter the world around [b]Raziel[/b] a bit, allowing him to reach places that can't be reached in the material realm. Naturally, while it's pretty easy to see the original [b]Ocarina[/b] under all that, it's hard not to admire just how cool and impressive the concept of [b]Soul Reaver[/b] is. Especially since the world around you will change in real time during the switch. You'll also visit quite a lot of the familiar places from the first game, so, there's still a lot of fun for those who loved the original.

Sure, the game had its own share of flaws. For example, [b]SR[/b] had way, [i]way[/i] too many cube puzzles. I have nothing against those puzzles as is, but having at least half of gameplay revolving around moving and rotating the stone cubes? It gets [i]really[/i] old an annoying fast. Also, despite being the best-looking version, the [b]PC[/b] port doesn't have rumble feature from [b]PS1[/b] and [b]Dreamcast[/b]. And let me tell you – rumble feature in this game was very good. You love rumble feedback? I totally recommend you to go for one of the console versions instead. Also, some decisions here feel pretty weird. For example, [b]Tony Jay[/b] (who previously voiced [b]Mortanius[/b]) will now appear as [b]Raziel[/b]'s new master – a [b]Lovecraftian[/b] being called [b]Elder God[/b]. Technically, there were some plans to play on that, but those were canned and as the result... it feels weird. Especially since, as the director of the game ([b]Amy Hennig[/b]) once said - “[i][b]Tony[/b] has a great voice, but it's always clear that it's him.[/i]” The decision to cast him as the [b]Elder God[/b] even led to the actor change for [b]Mortanius[/b] in [b]Legacy of Kain: Defiance[/b]. Like I said, really weird decision.

Then again, all of those things were pretty much unavoidable. [b]CD[/b] took the series away from its original creators and tried to build something new, based on their own vision. Facing their own difficulties and making their own mistakes. But did they succeed in the end? Oh, yeah... Despite being a drastically different thing, [b]LoK 2[/b] became a thing on its own. Charming, unique and full of interesting ideas (one of which was actually an [b]OoT[/b] time traveling,  but we won't play much with it until [b]SR 2[/b]), it was one of the most notable games from the fifth generation. One of the best-looking ones too and up to this day? It's still a charming and satisfying experience. Dixi.

93073977.review:
[b]Note:[/b] I wrote this review before seeing that Square Enix had temporarily removed the game from sale. Hopefully they're fixing it up because I can't recommend [i]Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver[/i] in its present state. There are fixes for the patient, but even when applied there’s no guarantee you won’t run into more problems.

But it’s such an amazing game that I can’t resist leaving a few thoughts on it! I'll remove the note if / when the fixes are applied.

[i]“Raziel...you are worthy.”[/i]

Nosgoth is a benighted land; no one, not the malformed vampires who prowl it nor the disparate humans who hunt them, is free of its corruption. Sacrificed to the contemptible hubris of one individual, Nosgoth is ticking inexorably towards doom.

Ruling over this apocalypse is the individual in question – vampire master Kain. His dominance is near worthless, sustained only by his hatred and some other, darker purpose. When one of his lieutenants evolves before him – growing bat-like wings – he has them thrown into the Lake of the Dead for the transgression.

This is Raziel, who is spared from his fate by a mysterious entity deep within the underworld, and offered a reprieve: become the entity’s ‘soul reaver’, and a license to exact vengeance on Kain will be granted. Raziel, yet to perceive such a thing as choice, accepts, and returns to Nosgoth to embark on a bloody odyssey.

Crystal Dynamics’ [i]Soul Reaver[/i] is a game I know well. I can [i]hear[/i] it whenever I imagine Nosgoth. A brilliant introduction to the rich Gothic fantasy world Silicon Knights had established in [i]Blood Omen[/i] a few years prior, the opening is notable even now for the strength of its writing, voice acting (Tony Jay is here!), and haunting, unforgettable soundtrack.

And that’s just the beginning of a dark, brooding story that takes place in a surprisingly expansive open world. Raziel climbs cavernous cathedrals, plunges into submerged abbeys and treks across frozen wastes, sounding every bit the Romanticist anti-hero whenever he chides his siblings for their grotesque devolution.

It’s so transparent he’s the oblivious plaything of two warring monsters whose antagonism spills out across time, but there’s just the right amount of indignant nobility in his manner that endears you to him all the same.

That nobility jars beautifully with his visage. He is a broken spectre; to float across pits he must hold the tip of his wrecked wings – a sad imitation of the flight evolution had gifted him. A brilliant creation, Raziel comfortably finds his place alongside Kain in the main narrative.

It’s not always easy to play. There’s far too much finicky platforming to be wholly enjoyable, and Crystal Dynamics never found a room they couldn’t defile with a box puzzle. But largely it’s a compelling third-person adventure, with enjoyable combat that can be enhanced by the discovery of glyphs and other power-ups. The ability to move between the physical and spectral realms is also super impressive, craftily woven into the world and gameplay.

Its flaws, such as they are, are specific to the era in which it was made. But the gap between now and then is always growing, and with it players’ tolerance for such flaws. I think there’ll always be an audience for the likes of [i]Soul Reaver[/i], but it’ll continue to narrow until it is the preserve of the very few.

That's a shame. [i]Soul Reaver[/i] was a masterwork of its day and arguably the finest entry in a grand and engrossing (if increasingly convoluted) series. Play this, then play the rest. Finicky platforming aside, I promise it's worth your time - you won't find a better vampiric rumination on freewill and destiny anywhere.

And it sounds like Square Enix are putting the work in to make it playable again. That's awesome.

"Become my soul reaver... my angel of death!"

Where do I begin with this masterpiece of a game. I remember when I got PS 1 magazine, which came with a CD full of demo games, one of them was this. That's the first time ever I played it and was super intrigued from the very start. I was like 7 years old at the time. Then the full game came out and I immediately fall in love with it! I didn't had a memory card back then, so I was replaying it over and over and over, because I couldn't save my progress, but I still loved it no matter what.
Since then I've replayed it a dozen of times and now as of writing this review, I've replayed it and finished it last night. 

First off, this game has the best opening FMV I've ever seen. I've played hundreds of games over my life and not a single one comes close to this. The way it was shot, the amazing music, all the characters, voice acting, world building, it's just pure perfection and every time I replay the game, I never skip it and always get chills.
Since I've mentioned music, soundtrack for this game is just great, so much atmosphere conveyed into it, unique, twisted and interesting (even have it on my phone and listen to it often when I go for a walk).
Voice acting is on another level and this game, at that time where voice acting was usually not taken very seriously, took it super seriously and every one nails their roles, especially Michael Bell and Simon Templeman. Especially how dialogue is very "shakespearean" like, you just enjoy listening these characters talk to each other or narrating the plot. Story and world building is great, you really get engaged into this twisted world that has changed over the millenium. Atmosphere is top notch, one of the main things I prefer this one over sequels. As far as combat goes, it's serviceable, I mean nothing ground breaking, but it serves it's purpose. Games has lots of puzzles, which are not hard and you can get them pretty fast if you just think for a minute, some of them are even super obvious. Game overall is not that difficult, you basically can't die, if you lose your full health, you get to the spectral realm and if you lose your health there, you just get back to the beginning of the game (not losing progress no worries). Which brings me to probably most unique mechanic: you can shift between spectral and physical realm. All the environment changes depending on which realm are you, and that is used often in puzzle solving or moving through zones. Boss fights are super easy tho and they are more of a puzzle solve, than actual fighting, it's more about the exchanges between characters. I won't spoil anything else, I could go on and on about the positives, but I'll leave rest untold, for more surprises. Visually, game is dated, but still has some art style that doesn't makes it terrible looking, and for that time, it was ahead of the time, especially when you consider that this game has ZERO loading screens, which is impressive on its own.

All that being said, games has issues of course, no game is perfect. As for me, the biggest issue I have is probably most have/will have, it's the camera and not so great controls. It sometimes gets super frustrating when you are platforming or moving blocks (oh trust me you will hate those block puzzles, I'm used to them so I don't mind them that much). For the newcomers, it might be kinda hard to know where to go or what to do, because there's no map, cursor, compass or anything like that in the game. And the game is semi-open world (but mostly linear), and the only indication you get where to go next is, for example, after boss fight, you'll be told like "On the east of that and that, there will be that place where you need to go" and that's it. Literally that's all the hint you get, no menu to open up and see objective, nothing. You are forced to explore and think logically where you would need to go. It's not that hard as it sounds, but it can get off putting for newcomers. Box puzzles can get repetitive too for the newcomers. 

This game is really unique gem, it's sad that franchise is basically dead nowadays, it 100% deserves a "RE2 type" remake. It's not really that much of a game how it is experience, I don't know. It's just something special and I recommend it to everyone. It has its flaws, but the good parts definitely over shadow the bad parts, I mean just voice acting alone does that. It has a special place in my heart and its easily in my top 10 games off all time! I try to replay it once every year at least, and as I was replaying it these last 2 days, I really really enjoyed it, if I could experience it again for the first time, I would love it.

Buy it and enjoy!

This was, at one time, probably the best 3d platformer you could own, well horror wise. There are 2 games from this era I really love and its this one, and shadowman. That said, lets get into why SR1 is so great.

If you ever played super metroid, then you might know what to expect here. SR1 consists of a huge hub world. You have a spot in the game where you can use a waypoint to teleport to different areas of the game. You can find health upgrades and runes that teach magic abilities. You can also explore the game narrative and proceed, fighting bosses and doing puzzles much like zelda. As you play more you will eventually get to the final encounter with kain. The games pretty long it took me about 20 hours to beat it. Its not as long as shadowman which can take far longer to fully complete but it is a pretty lengthy game. The combat is also pretty good, as not only can you slash your claws, but you can also grab weapons like spears. Chuck them through monsters, impale them, or just hack them to bits. You can also grab enemies and toss them into spikes, or water since we all know what water does to vamps. It has some great strategy in combat, and the bosses also have specific ways to beat them. Imo SR2 was a bit of a downgrade from SR1 for taking out some of the fighting mechanics in 1 but eh, SR2 is still worth playing.

Its nowhere near as good as SR1 however. Also comparing SR1 to games of the time is a good idea. At the time it came out, it really did look and play better than any 3d game on psx imo. N64 is different, but about the only ones I can compare SR1 to are spyro and ape escape. It really was an impressive game for its time. [b] Story: [/b] Didn't finish, can't rate, seemed passable.

[b] Music 5/10: [/b] It's ok, but I don't remember anything.

[b] Voice Acting 5/10: [/b] Once again, it works fine. Gotta remember this came out in '99.

[b] Combat 6/10: [/b] It works surprisingly well, and I did enjoy the large number of ways to dispatch your foes, but it gets repetitive very quickly. While there is a dodge ability, you don't really need to use it; you can just walk out of the way. Though it does suffer from being a spamfest.

[b] World Interactivity 9/10: [/b] Especially for it's time, the amount you can do is phenomenal. Picking up anything that looks like you can pick it up, throwing everything, picking up and throwing enemies, relighting torches... it's all great. I just wish you could do as much in more modern games.

[b] Character Design 6/10: [/b] I mean, having an ugly, disfigured, emaciated protagonist is original.

[b] (Keyboard) Controls 2/10: [/b] These are just terrible, actually painful. Movement is super clunky and imprecise. You can only rotate the camera clockwise by holding a button, otherwise it is just over-the-shoulder. There's also a button to snap it in the direction Raziel is facing, but half the time it just clips into him so you can't see anything. And you can't look up at all, which really makes it hard to navigate many spaces. It just feels bad to play. Also, doors are hard and trying to be in the exact right position to pick something up gets tedious.

[b] Game Issues: [/b] Tutorials seem to be really hit-or-miss. As in sometimes they just don't happen when they should be triggered. And because nearly everything is contextual you can't just look up the controls in the options.

[b] Overall 4/10 [/b] 
[b] Personal Enjoyment 3/10 [/b]

I think there's a great game buried in this mess, but with the technical issues and its general aging, I can't recommend this. Maybe if someone finds a way to fix the controller issues... I don't know.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#179 out of 555)... it's time for Soul Reaver.

Soul Reaver, Soul Reaver, Soul Reaver. What can I say? It's not the first entry in the Legacy of Kain series, but it's the first -proper- entry. Picking up after the "bad ending" of Blood Omen (unavailable on PC) Soul Reaver introduces one of the best-told stories in games history. The actual game itself -- the running about and the slaying of foes and solving of puzzles and all that jazz -- is fairly unremarkable and hasn't aged very well at all. This is an early-era PS1 game, and it shows. But that's not really the main draw of the series: no, the main draw here is the story. Which is fully voiced by some of the most talented voice actors the industry has ever known.

By modern standards Soul Reaver is a bit of a clumsy, clunky mess. It can be hard to see past its anachronistic design. But I strongly advise you to try. Soul Reaver begins the tale of Raziel and Kain, a story full of betrayal and triumph, villains and (anti)heroes, destiny and destruction. It can be a bit melodramatic at times, but it all works astonishingly well. Better than it should. The story here told is leagues ahead of any story anyone else was doing at the time, and considerably better than most of the game stories told since.

Note: also played on Sony Playstation 1.

[quote][h1]TL;DR[/h1]
This masterpiece is a milestone in gaming history and if you haven't played it, you owe it to yourself to do so right now![/quote]

[h1][i]»Soul Reaver and Reaver of Souls, your destinies are intertwined.«[/i][/h1]

Soul Reaver, the sequel to the 1996 game [i]Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain[/i], is an Action Adventure game set in the decaying world of [i]Nosgoth[/i], more than a millenium after the vampire Kain made a consequentious decision: As the Guardian of the corrupted Pillar of Balance, after killing all the other Guardians, he was supposed to sacrifice himself in order to allow new Guardians for each Pillar to be born and the Pillars to be restored thus. However, after a great purge, Kain was the last remaining vampire and dying then and there would have made the species extinct. [i]Kain refused the sacrifice![/i]

The game introduces the player to a desolate world where humanity has become all but extinct, the Pillars remain broken and almost all life has gone extinct due to Kain's momentous defiance of fate. Raziel, this game's protagonist, is the first-born of Kain's new vampires and his most trusted general, having served him a thousand years. All is about to change for him, however, when he develops the gift of flight by growing two bat-like wings. Seemingly in an act of jealousy, Kain tears the bones from Raziel's wings and has him cast into the deadly abyss by two of Raziel's own brethren. An eternity later, Raziel, now deformed, awakens in the spectral realm and is greeted by his apparent savior, the Elder God.

And so his quest for vengeance and to restore order and balance begins . . .

[h1]🎮 Gameplay[/h1]

Soul Reaver combines Action Adventure gameplay reminiscent of Tomb Raider's with a Metroid-vania like progression, close quarters, tactical combat and a variety of puzzles, while innovating the genre and games as a whole with its [i]plane-shifting[/i] gameplay mechanics and its [i]data-streaming[/i] game engine:
[list]
[*] [b]Plane-shifting[/b]
Raziel, now being a wraith, has the ability to switch between the material realm (the world we inhabit) and the spectral realm (a distorted version of our world inhabited by the souls of the dead). Shifting from one plane to the other seamlessly morphs parts of the world around Raziel, locking and unlocking certain passages to him. This, at the time, was an unprecedented novelty and critically acclaimed for its innovative nature.
[*] [b]Data-streaming[/b]
The game constantly pre-loads the next section of the map and keeps the previous section loaded (and in two versions each - material and spectral realm), meaning that, no matter if you turn back or move forward, the next section will already be loaded. This effectively eliminates loading times, allowing the player to travel from the start of the game to the very end of the game world without a single loading screen. Of course, starting the game as well as quick-travelling still requires loading the section you're visiting but other than that the game cleverly managed to feel like the first open-world title of its time.[/list]

[b]Puzzles[/b] include block puzzles, puzzles involving realm shifting and puzzles that require unlocking new abilities and returning with them later. Due to the abundance of the first kind, the game has been criticized as being somewhat repetetive.

[b]Combat[/b] in the game is tailored to one-on-one encounters and involves a tactical element in most fights due to the vampiric enemies being immortal. Fighting the offspring of one of the vampire generals requires stunning them and then eliminating them using one of several environmental hazards (water, fire, sunlight, spikes) or one of several weapons or tools (torches to ignite or weapons to impale through the heart). Once the enemy is dead, its soul is released and Raziel can then absorb it to restore lost health. Doing so will dissolve the enemy's body, allowing Raziel to retrieve his weapon. Failing to absorb the soul in time means it goes to the spectral realm (where Raziel can follow and absorb it still, dissolving the enemy's body even then). Retrieving the weapon without dissolving the body first results in the enemy being instantly resurrected. This intricate system means that, even after the fight is over, the tactical aspect isn't. Additionally, neither devouring the soul, nor retrieving the weapon results in the enemy staying dead forever, meaning it won't respawn upon a later return to the area, adding even more tactical possibilities to the game.

Upon defeating one of the several bosses, Raziel gains a new ability that in turn allows progression in previously unreachable places. These abilities, one by one, open new parts of the world for a [b]Metroid-vania like progression[/b].

On top of those abilities, the game also features [b]large, optional dungeons[/b] that allow the player to unlock powerful Glyphs that can stun, damage and/or eliminate large groups of enemies in style. These dungeons add to the playtime, feature thematic puzzles and locations and rewarding special abilities. One of them, the Fire Glyph dungeon, also was the content of a PlayStation demo of the game.

[h1]📖 Story / Presentation[/h1]

The story of Soul Reaver is a classical, almost Shakesperean revenge story of a fallen anti-hero seeking vengeance against his despot former master but with a hell of a cliffhanger ending that promises a much deeper plot about deception, betrayal, conspiracy and defiance, told in a highly elevated (again, almost Shakesperean) language by extremely talented and charismatic voice-actors. The plot may appear simple but with its superb presentation, it just works, draws you in, doesn't let you go and, in the end, leaves you longing for the continuation (although, luckily, you won't have to wait two years for it, nowadays).

[h1]🎼 Soundtrack[/h1]

The score, especially Raziel's theme (the intro theme and that of the Razielim territory) »Ozar Midrashim 1.1« by Information Society, are perfectly fitting of the dark, dystopian, gothic setting of the game and are extremely memorable. Writing this review is a trip down memory lane, listening to the track mentioned above!

[h1]💻 Graphics / Art-style[/h1]

While the graphics have definitely aged poorly (the game was released two decades ago, mind you), Soul Reaver was a technical accomplishment of its time and definitely looked the part. The art-style is dark, gothic, visceral - perfect for what this game is. Additionally, with the introduction of the spectral realm where some sort of distortion is constantly present and with the tentacles of the Elder God, the gothic castles and (mostly) abandoned cities and many other details, the game also evokes a Lovecraftean vibe.

[h1]💰 Business Model[/h1]

[quote][u]Classic:[/u]
Buy the game, play the game.
No paid DLCs, items, lootboxes.[/quote]

[h1]📋 Conclusion[/h1]

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver holds a very, very special place in my heart and is easily one of my favorite games of all time...

But even without the goggles of Nostalgia, that wretched beast, Soul Reaver is a milestone of gaming history, features one part of a huge and deep story and superb voice acting by Michael Bell as protagonist Raziel, Simon Templeman as antagonist Kain, Anna Gunn as Balance Guardian spirit Ariel, Richard Doyle as Time-Streamer Moebius (all three reprising their roles from the original Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain) and late Tony Jay as the Elder God, and very creative game mechanics. It's definitely worth your time and attention, if you've never played it and a revisit if you have.

The second entry in the Legacy of Kain series, Soul Reaver is a classic action/adventure game with a compelling story, high-quality voice acting, an engrossing gothic atmosphere, and sub-par gameplay.

I don't want to spoil much in terms of story, because it truly is the best part of the game. You don't necessarily have to know the story of Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain to play it and grasp the plot, but it does help, as this game touches on the lore of Nosgoth, and of the ambitions of Kain, vampire-conquerer of the world.

This game has you playing as one of Kain's former vampire lieutenants, Raziel, who was betrayed and cast into oblivion, where he became a wraith. Fueled by vengeance, and with the ability to shift between planes (the main mechanical gimmick that makes the gameplay more compelling than it has any right to be), Raziel sets out to claim his revenge on the vampires and Kain himself.

The exploration is decent and there are many secret items and areas to find, but the combat and puzzles are truly patience-testing. This game features more block puzzles than should be allowed in any game, and is at times so tedious that finishing the game can seem like a chore.

However, the story and characters are so compelling that the slog is, in the end, worth it in my eyes. The game definitely needs to be played and appreciated by more people.

The PC port on steam has some issues (maybe too many, but I found lots of guides for fixes and made it work in time), and is almost unplayable in its base state. Sound issues abound, as well as controller issues and a lot of crashes. 54217547.review:
One of my favourite games of all time, but I will try to keep any bias away in this review. Also while I did play the PS1-version a lot, this review is for the PC-version.

The story and voice acting are probably the games strongest points. Even to this day, the acting is of pretty high quality and the dialogue has a very Shakespeare feel to it.

Something to note is that this is actually the second game in the "Legacy of Kain"-franchise with the first being "Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain". Sadly, "Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain" is not available on Steam and "Soul Reaver" — as well as most other games in the franchise — references several events that happened in the first game which could lead to some confusion, but shouldn't impact your experience too much.
You play as Raziel after he gets betrayed by his master Kain, who was the main character in the first game in the series. Raziel is thrown into the abyss, but instead of dying he somehow survives and lives on as a wraith. You then proceed to travel through Nosgoth seeking revenge on Kain for his treachery.

The gameplay is pretty similar to other 3D adventure games of the era such as Tomb Raider or Legend of Zelda. You have to solve puzzles, fight enemies and acquire new abilities in order to proceed. The combat is similar to that of Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time in that you can focus on a particular enemy when fighting groups of them. However, most enemies can't be defeated by simply hitting them and instead requires you to either use certain weapons, spells or the environment to finish them off.
One of the games most interesting mechanics is the ability to shift between the Material- and Spectral realms. Depending on which realm you are in, the environment will change and certain abilities can only be used in certain realms.

Despite my love for the game and franchise, a lot of aspects of the game hasn't aged well.
The controls feel a bit dated and along with the camera can make it a little bit frustrating, especially if you are required to do some more precise platforming. I highly advice using a controller and maybe getting a program to allow you to rebind the keys since playing this game with a keyboard is not something I would recommend. You could always get the "Controller Companion" on Steam to accomplish this.

The graphics are not the greatest compared to a lot of games today, but considering it's a game that was released for the original PlayStation and Dreamcast that would come as no surprise.

The music is very atmospheric and doesn't really stick out or take the central stage. It tends to be in the background and it does in my opinion accomplishes it's purpose just fine.

While I myself haven't really encountered too many issues when it comes to crashing, there have been reports of others having issues while playing the game on more modern hardware and such so be mindful of that.


All in all, I'd say that if you'd like to get into a classic franchise with a pretty interesting story that contains vampires as well as dark, gothic themes then check this game out. The PC version is probably not the optimal version to play, but should be just fine if you can get a controller to work.

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver 1 is a classic 3D action brawler from the Playstation/Dreamcast era. (LoK:SR2 is garbage, but don't let that put you off the first one)

Firstly, watch the trailer. If you can't handle crappy 32-bit graphics then I get it. Skip this one. Wait for the HD Remaster that has never been announced, but will probably eventually come.

But if you can get past the polygons then trust me the game is worth it. I beat this game on my old Playstation 1 and then again on Dreamcast. The story is dumb but the game has this cool gothic horror style that really appealed to me as a teenager. I don't know why.

The game opens with a decent looking cutscene. Basically you are a vampire, but oh damn you grew wings and daddy is jealous. So your vampire brothers throw you into hell. For some reason. But it doesn't kill you. Just kinda maims you. You wake up half dead in hell because Kain wants wings and not you. I guess.

Gameplay wise it's a fun time. Your wings are damaged but you can still glide around and you unlock new abilities with each boss fight that let you find new areas to explore. It's not particularly easy, but you can't really lose the game. If your health gets low you fall into some sort of soul dimension and can refill your life. If you die there you just get sent back to the start, which can be annoying, but not too bad since you get new shortcuts with each new ability. (If I remember correctly). Plus transitioning into this soul realm can alter the landscape so it affects your exploration as well.

The combat is simple but the addition of random weapons and torches add impalement and immolation to your repertoire and the animations for killing the enemies are classic old school pixel blood and violence.

The one issue is it kind of ends on a story cliffhanger and the second game completely ruined the battle system and is unplayable in my opinion, but really the story is too weird to matter anyway. Play it so you can burn the vampire empire to the ground for revenge! And maybe because God wants you to. Not sure about that one.

If you like old school action hack n slash 3D, but bad graphics games then this one really stands out as a must play, but honestly it's not for everyone.

At least not until it gets the Medievil treatment and they rerelease it with fully upgraded graphics. A goth can dream...

Overall Summary: This is a hidden gem from the Sega Dreamcast. Buy it!

Type of game: 
Puzzle solver with a bit of combat. It will require patience to get through!

Price: 
£0.69p on steam sale! (summer 2018) – you can’t go wrong for this price!

Highlights I want to mention: 
Other reviews have already noted the excellent storyline, music and voice acting so I will just add that the story is also very interesting from a philosophical point of view in regards to the concepts of free will and judging actions on face value. Also, the characters seem to be named after angels e.g. main character is Raziel (seems to be similar to ‘Azrael’ - the angel of death). The boss battles are very good but require you to use tactics rather than fight them head on - there was one boss battle in particular (in the water abbey) which took me a long time to complete!

Notable frustrations:
The camera angles are a real nuisance so you will regularly need to press the camera button to look in the right direction, especially when jumping ledges. Some puzzles are also quite difficult but very rewarding once solved. The graphics are as expected for a game from the 1990s.

Compatibility Issues: 
The game didn’t seem to be compatible with my PS3 controller set up (some of the buttons don’t get recognised) but this doesn’t matter as it playable with the keyboard. Also, I am on windows 7 and on rare occasions the game did crash and a few times the sound became unsynchronised but this was not that frequent. 

Good to know:
One final thing to mention is that the story of this game spans across multiple games (Soul Reaver 2, Blood Omen 2, legacy of Kain defiance) so don’t expect a conclusion here. I haven’t got to the final game yet but I understand from research that there was meant to be a further game after defiance so I think it doesn’t conclude fully – I know this will put some people off so thought it was worth mentioning.

43721298.review:
Soul Reaver is the second installment in the brilliant Legacy of Kain series. The first game, Blood Omen - is unfortunately not on Steam. However, this may be for the better, as it would have likely been realized entirely incapable of being even started as with the rest of the series with the exception of maybe Defiance. But what can be said of Blood Omen, was that it had a crisp, inspired aesthetic, jotted down only by the limitation of games in its time, the console hardware it was structured around and some genuinely goofy little parts here and there that took you out of the immersion. Overall, it was an intriguing and sometimes, more often than not, a bit frustrating. However, the plot is very relevant to Soul Reaver, which takes little time to give you any introspective beyond some name drops here and there in the beginning and throughout. 

Essentially, Kain is a nobleman who is reluctant in accepting his Dark Gift of Vampirism. Eventually, by the end of the game, he finds himself rather fond of this new found form and had become one some may call, evil incarnate. Given the chance to sacrifice himself to the Pillars of Nosgoth, which are vital to the survival of the world through their sustainment, Kain does the unthinkable. He executes free will and frees himself from the claws of Causality, however - history abhors a paradox and the consequences have not yet become visible to him. 

Many years later, his subordinate Raziel basically flexes on him with a mutation that harkenening back to an older race of Vampires, now extinct. A revered one, at that - even if just remembered by few, Kain included. Of course, Kain (who as Raziel explains in the beginning, is basically a demi-god) being a vampire God-King of rational mind, does the only responsible thing and breaks Raziel's wings and has his own bothers in arms throw him into a swirling toilet bowl of suffering. Raziel is centuries later, resurrected by a mysterious force and the Wheel of Causality sets into motion. This is the basic plot of Soul Reaver and boy does it only get more confusing from here on end.

Storywise, the game is a master piece, its best parts being only amplified and emphasized by creative, original environments and a rich soundtrack that is both gothic, industrial and surreal. For the time it came out, this game was utterly fantastic. It had fantastic graphics and didn't suffer from texture stuttering that other PS1 games at the time were known for (Tenchu 2 is especially heinous in this regard, where almost every cutscene and environment in the game can be a flickering mess at times, with meshes eating each other and just blatantly tearing itself apart at the seams.) Soul Reaver has aged poorly, but something about PS1 graphics make it very special, in a way - it is much like Raziel himself. A corpse inhibited with a very strong life that wishes to live.

The depth of the designs in Soul Reaver is simply astonishing. What is portrayed within the confines of blocky meshes and enormous environments is consistent with the vision  of the overly ambitious team behind the game. Of course, much of the game later on feels rushed but for the most part - there are almost no games that look like Soul Reaver outside of its own series. Making it one of the most distinct games I have ever played. Its mix of ethereal architecture and lore-driven environments, death as a gameplay mechanic, the difficult - semi-open world gameplay... It is unironically the Dark Souls before its time. However, while Dark Souls borrows most of its aesthetic and general concepts from other sources like Berserk, Soul Reaver and the LoK series in general is distinct, original and has a very pretentious, Shakespearean form of story telling which makes it an all time classic.

The characters, the motivations and the voice acting far exceed the gameplay. Which has aged terribly. Especially the PC version. That being said, the PC release itself overall is super clunky and at times, down right dog shit. The worst sin however, is the version that Steam has decided to sell. This game was literally unplayable when I got it, I had to download a fan fix, run it in compatibility mode for XP service pack 3 and set core affinity to use only a single one just for the game to function. Even then, I ran into some crashes and immense bull-ass drainage like the sound effect loop glitches that persists in all versions of the PC port. 

The biggest problem with this particular version is that it is so obviously a half hearted port to PC and Steam has done nothing to rectify this irredeemabley, often unplayable game right out of the original booting. Apparently even the GOG version works better and is more stable without fan fixes, I even read one suggestion on the steam discussion forums here about fixing the game by simply "pirating the GOG version and replacing the .exe steam provided". Just think about that for a minute. When I did get this game going, it was honestly a lot of fun, even with the keyboard controls I painstakingly rebinded to being half competent and controllable. All of my actual gripes for this game can't be justified, as the console versions are obviously superior, despite the crispness and higher resolutions the PC version provides. This game was meant for the PS1 controller and it shows. 

Without guides and youtube walkthroughs, this game will probably take you 12-20 hours to beat. Easily. Even then, if you were to consult a written walkthrough there is an immense chance that it was written by someone about as soulful as the dreadful husks of vampires Raziel encounters through the game. It is strange, as this game was surely a part of many people's childhoods, but even semi-modern guides are seemingly written by both the elementarily illiterate and the profoundly incapable, as far as lexicon goes. I understand the problem here, however - Legacy of Kain is an incredibly hard game to describe. However, things such as glass planes have been described as "weights", complex directions have been simplified to "go right, jump left, fly toward the thing and go through and jump again" and puzzles that would otherwise take a few sentences to describe, sometimes go off on triads of shitty jokes and attempts at self reflective humour in many of the walkthroughs. One in particular was super cringe worthy, as if written by a 14 year old who just discovered the internet (I sincerely disbelieve such a thing is possible however, the people who fully appreciate and can even beat these games had to have been young adults to even comprehend what the fuck was going on) and was essentially him roleplaying as Kain. Other than that, the community for this game and franchise is loving and I am madly nostalgic for it. 

At the time of writing this review, I beat the game in little over 9 hours. This is only because as a kid, I had to learn this game the hard way and I specifically remember probably putting in at least 40 hours into my first playthrough. It was damn nigh impossible at the time, before convenient internet searches, before well written walkthroughs, before youtube and at most, I had a strategy guide that only got me through the first level/the demo. 

If you hate backtracking, if you hate metroidvania games, if you hate puzzles (and unforgiving ones) and games that make you say outloud "what the fuck am I supposed to do" and "why do I have to do this again?" - then surely, you will hate this game in everyway. However, for those people - I highly recommend at least watching all of the cutscenes on youtube. After all, I am a firm believer that the LoK series is golden for its story and not its gameplay. Other than that, I can recommend this game to the original fans such as myself, who wanted to - after many years, complete the love they had of this game by playing through it one more time.

OK. I knew I was getting into the retro-gaming zone the very moment I decided to play this. And this is very retro. The story is good and entertaining. The atmosphere is interesting and goes along with the supernatural theme. Guess this is all I can praise about the game. And is not the game's fault. See, when this game was new, vampires were monsters back in the day. Fascinating night creatures. A game about vampires was bounded for success. Then the entertainment industry took these bloodthirsty monsters and turned them into a joke (Buffy, Twightlight) and the exploitation and over-exposure of the vampire in all media made them as interesting as the zombies are now (also totally over-used and heading fast to the forgotten monsters realm). 

So, the point to all this is that the story is interesting only as a good tale but is no longer fascinating and the 'horror' element is lost. 

Now, I like retro-gaming and I know I'll face many challenges with an old game. You need patience. This game test that patience. No mouse, only keyboard. Punching several keys while fighting is tedious. 3 keys to jump and get over obstacles. Tedious. So the controls are old and are kinda boring to deal with nowadays. But that's not the really annoying thing, that's the saving system. Yeah, you can save anywhere, but whenever you load the game you always return to the starting point and you must do your way all over again to the point where you left the game. At times you need to fight again the same creatures or do that hard jump that took you many tries before. Or just run again through the unnecessary long hallways with no other purpose than to reach the before mentioned 'save' spot. So, in order to avoid this, you need to finish any level in one sit to reach the 'true saving point": the start of each level. If this doesn't break your will, then you might have fun with this.

Found no bugs. I only had one crash, but I was messing around with stuff. Runs fine on win 7.

Besides the controls and the saving system, this game is a lot about solving puzzles, puzzles that are also pretty long to solve but something that was standard when this game was fresh and this was originally a console game. Whenever I'm playing a game, one thing out of three usually happens to me: I don't want to keep playing, I don't want the game to end cause is so much fun or I want to keep playing just to finish the damn thing as fast as possible cause I won't let it beat me, even when it feels more like a chore than anything else. This game falls into the third category.

So I recommend it only if you like a good story, you still like vampires, you are very patient, you don't mind to fight with the controls as much as with the enemies and if you're driven by nostalgia. The game's plagued with so many problems, I should've said this negatively, but the game itself is so great so I can't bear to. What a shame.

Although the predecessor is not on Steam (Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain), it'd be a good idea if you can grab a copy of it somewhere and play it first. No, it's not necessary to play it before Soul Reaver, but it's a starting point since this series has very complex but brilliantly made story.

Steam's Soul Reaver is basically a broken port, almost unplayable in today's machines -- it's incompatible with Windows 10, but if you can get it to start, then your effort is paid off. Check [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/224920/discussions/0/846944689653666452/?ctp=4]here[/url], [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/224920/discussions/0/352788917751417358/]here[/url], and [url=https://github.com/afradley/soulreaver-gamepad-fix]gamepad fix here[/url], for some good info.

Now on to the game. If you have never played any Soul Reaver before and not willing to play Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain first, it's also no problem. While there are references to the old game, it doesn't mean the game does not explain anything to you. In fact, Soul Reaver starts the mood for the latter games (Soul Reaver 2 and Legacy of Kain: Defiance) and they're tied together chronologically. It'd be a good idea to listen to the dialogues so you can understand the story. And yes, understanding the story means you are getting the best part of the game. Korean-drama lovers would hate the story whole-hardheartedly though, it's the complete opposite as it's filled with hatred, anger, bitter vengeance and betrayal.

Graphic is a bit old and outdated and even my friend called it 'hurting the eyes'. If you see it that way, it's not wrong. This game is made more than a decade ago, it's ok to be outdated. It was revolutionary when it was released, though. More so, in-game option is pretty much useless, there's no standard graphic option we see everywhere nowadays like AA/Blur/FPS limiter etc, so you need to bear with it. 

Gameplay-wise, It's notably similar to Capcom's Devil May Cry as 3d action-platformer but less arcadey and more puzzles. Fighting is not that smooth and fluid unlike DmC, but it's not that complicated either as DmC combos. One-third of the game you'll acquire Soul Reaver and it'll remain your best weapon throughout the series, not just this game, a sign that the game doesn't care too much about combat mechanic and just want to present the best story mainly. Block Puzzles are everywhere in this game and can draw some ire if you can't stand it but alas it's a necessary stuff to finish to progress in the game.

Sound-wise, it's pretty much excellent. This port retains everywhere the old PSX copy has including voice acting. Yes, the game's fully voiced and the Voice Actors are ridiculously good, so good that none of modern games can even compare to this game's in my opinion. BGMs is Gothic and present the atmosphere fittingly, one of the best BGM set I've listened to for PSX era.

Overall, a great game wrapped in a broken port. If you can acquire the game elsewhere, do it. If you can't, Steam offers the game pretty cheap when it's on sale so it doesn't hurt you too much.

36728252.review:
Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is an old game with a very cool name.

Five hundred years after the events of Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain. Kain is  deified, having built a great vampiric Empire across the entirety of Nosgoth. Which is bad for us because we're people and filled with that red stuff they like to drink. 
They bite me and I go “Ouch.” 

Raziel, firstborn of Kain's lieutenants, and commander of the Razielim, one of the clans of Kain's empire. One fateful day, after Raziel reveals that he has surpassed his master in evolution by growing some neat wings. Kain tears his wings from his body and casts Raziel into the abyss, a whirlpool that burns the flesh from Raziel's bones. 

But Raziel is resurrected by a strange entity known as the Elder God. The Elder God tells Raziel of the wheel of fate and that he has been resurrected as a “Soul Reaver”, a creature that consumes souls under the command of the Elder God. 

Now, Raziel returns to Nosgoth centuries later and finds out its all gone down the toilet. Kain's empire is rotting, all of the vampires are all goopy looking, and there are those human guys walking around and shooting at the goopy vampires with crossbows and other cool stuff. Raziel must now hunt down Kain, avenge himself and his clan, and bring balance to Nosgoth.

All while not even being bothered by the fact that he's naked from the chest down.

Legacy of Kain is one of those classics people don't seem to talk about anymore, though it kind of makes sense, since the series had pretty much run it's course. That being said, the game still holds up to this day. 

Soul Reaver is basically a marvel for it's time in both story telling and game play. It mixed platforming, puzzle solving, and combat in such a way that it fit the universe it took place in. You don't just fight and kill vampires, you straight up have to slay them, and use methods that other people have to use in universe to keep the bitey little bastards down.
If you impale a vampire, it goes down and stays down, as long as it remains impaled. So what happens if you pull the weapon out of the corpse? The vampire gets back up. So how do you keep the smelly idiot down for good? Well you dump it in water or force it into sunlight.  
Fortunately, Raziel can simply consume their souls after he has defeated them, giving them no chance of waking back up and giving Raziel a distinct advantage against some human who has to go toe to toe with a vampire. But it's just so cool that they took the time to just make combat lore-friendly to their own universe. 

Puzzles in Soul Reaver seem daunting at first, but you soon realize that they're a lot easier than they look. I've heard of people actually having to buy the Prima strategy guide for this back in the day, or go on Gamefaqs, but I didn't have a problem solving any of them. They're mostly block puzzles or some sort of jumping puzzle, luckily they're never so complicated that they wear out their welcome.
Many of the areas you're in later on are basically one giant puzzle, with a plethora of smaller little brain teasers in between that all add up to a singular goal. Its rewarding to mess around with a bunch of puzzles that all end up making something cool happen in the end.
Like a Rubik's cube or throwing a badger into a school bus.

The voice acting is pretty astounding. Both Simon Templeman as Kain and Michael Bell as Raziel bring it home with their almost Shakespearean line delivery, their dialogue, monologues, and quips are something writers today wish they had thought of. Even the Elder God, played by the late Tony Jay, chews up every scene their in. There isn't a bad bad or out of place voice in the game, though it helps that basically everybody is played by either Templeman, Bell, or Jay, save for a few exceptions.

Also, get your hands on the soundtrack, seriously, that's the good shit.

“Wow, Dirk!” You say. “You sure like this game! So what's wrong with it?”

Well, I'm glad you asked, person I just made up.

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver came out in 1999, and there hasn't been anything done with it since that day. There was no modern updates that I can think of, and fan patches can only go so far. 
As it stands on a fresh install, the game kind of looks like puke, it's pretty bumpy and blurry, and squirmy looking. Luckily, there is a resolution patch that makes the game look much better on a modern monitor. 

What cant be fixed is the controls. I don't usually have problems with older games, but I couldn't get around just how wonky the keyboard controls were. I ended up trying to use a controller, but the game basically only seems to work with old logitech controllers from the 90s. I ended up having to get a third party program just so I could basically jury-rig the game to work with a modern controller, but even then it was janky and barely worked. 

Luckily! Luckily. There is like, a million different ways to play this game.
You absolutely cannot go wrong with the PS1 version of the game, which is both easy to find physically as well as available digitally on the PS3. There's also the third option, you know what I'm talking about, wink wink nudge nudge.
The other option is the Dreamcast version, which is apparently the best version you can get. I myself can attest that this version is actually really good, it plays well and doesn't have the same problems as the PS1 version's slowdowns or the PCs weird control schemes. 

Whichever way you play it is up to you, this is more of a review of the game as a whole than a specific version. I don't care how you play it, but you should probably play it if you somehow haven't already. 
I have like, three more of these to go through anyway. 

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver gets 9 uses of the word “Degenerate” out of 10. 

Also, you all first played this on the Interactive 8 sampler demo disk on the playstation as well, right? Wasn't that thing the bomb? Medieval, Metal Gear, Cool Boarders, that one Ninja game. That thing was the best.

33908681.review:
Note: I have completed the disc version on PC, played the Steam version for about an hour with a custom patch I downloaded from the Steam forum because it crashes without it for me, and loaded up with the original exe to get Steam to recognize at least a few minutes of play so I could do a review.

On to my thoughts!

Much like Raziel's wings, I'm very torn here. The game's visuals, camera controls, a bit of clunkiness inherent of the era the game came out in, etc...numerous things are making the game a big cringey today, even though I played and enjoyed it when it was new enough, completing the game and liking it pretty well at the time. These aspects of the game could be a little divisive for players, since it's hard [i]not[/i] to notice how hard it is to look up or manage the camera at times, and how Raziel's jumps can be a little tough to anticipate at times, combat's a little clunky, etc.

I'm not prepared to say that Soul Reaver should just go away, though. What we have here is a bunch of great premises: a vampire turned into something else that consumes souls instead of blood, out to get revenge on the sire who wounded him, stealing powers from his brothers he destroys along the way, each of whom have mutated into freaking-cool-looking monstrosities, all while serving some mysterious cool-voiced underworld entity with fantastic voice acting and a cool setting. It has a good story and premise, great voice acting, and I [i]love[/i] using vampires' weaknesses to destroy them, such as chunking them into direct sunlight, impaling them, tossing them in water, lighting them on fire, etc. 

Nosgoth seems like a [i]really[/i] cool setting that technical limitations and budgetary concerns have been hampering its exposure to the world. We see a couple of humans in very brief about-to-die moments, which would have been fun to see expanded out a little into something more, to better feel the impact of the vampire scourge on Nosgoth. Older tech also meant less foliage, wall decorations, knick-knacks/details in indoor areas, and just such a bare-bones approach.

I guess what I'm getting at is that people who think the original game is perfect as is have that perfect experience they enjoy, while I would love to see a remake along the lines of the GameCube Resident Evil, in that virtually everything is improved while keeping the spirit and story of the original and all of the memorable stuff that was great. I would buy and play the living hell out of a remake of this game done with that level of improvement and modification to modernize, innovate, and yet still maintain the integrity of what matters most in the game.
