TL;DR: Unless you're willing to search for hours only to have inconsistent loads, don't waste your money.

I'm conflicted in my review.  The game is every bit as you remember it, be that good or bad.  You have 2 speeds: run and sprint, which often means falling off of small platforms.  The camera controls are some of the worst (no free control, only a quick snap to behind your character).  The story is as great as ever and the game does look better than it did in 1999 and the voice acting is still top notch.  

The problem, and the reason I can't recommend this game, is the problems getting it to even load.  The first time I got it to load, it took me 3 hours of trial and error.  The solution?  It loads perfectly once out of about 50 attempts.  No compatibility mode, no running as admin.  Just load, crash, load, crash, fiddle with settings, load, crash, load crash, default settings, load, crash, load, crash....(10 minutes later)..... load, works fine.  Seriously.  I managed to play it enough in 2 days to finish it but getting it to even start became a chore.  

Then there's the controller issues.  I used a wireless Xbox 360 controller (with the wireless receiver) and Pinnacle Game Profiler.  I recommend it.  Download the existing profile, then edit it.  The downloaded scheme is terrible.  Right trigger for attack, 2 buttons to devour souls, you get the idea.  I had one sound issue which forced me to restart the game (complete with several dozen crashes again), but otherwise it worked fine..... if you want to call it that.  If you're really jonesing for some nostalgia, watch a let's play on YouTube.  You'll save yourself a lot of frustration.

The Good:
+ Voice acting is still great
+ Story holds up

The Bad:
- Camera controls are still a mess

The Ugly:
-- Constant crashes at launch.

Bottom line: this game performs like an abusive significant other.  It's crash, after crash, after crash, and just when you're ready to give up, it loads and works perfectly making you remember all the wonderful times you had when you first played it; making you think it's worked out its issues. 32189192.review:
Amazing game. One of my all-time favourites, alongside Shadow of the Colossus, Metal Gear Solid 3 and Okami.

This game does not get the love it deserves, and it makes me sad.
You might have heard (and already forgotten by now) of Nosgoth. Well, if that's your idea of Legacy of Kain, please forget it. There is so much more to be appreciated in here than a shallow online shooter about vampire hunters and superpowered vampires.

I like to describe the earlier LoK games as simplified, darker, grittier counterparts to their Legend of Zelda contemporaries. Not only because I believe this will easily draw people's attention to them, but because they really kind of feel alike, gameplay-wise.
Blood Omen (the first game in the franchise, still unavailable on digital PC game stores such as Steam or GOG, unfortunately) kind of feels like A Link to the Past, with its early action-RPG gameplay and 3/4 perspective, although it might come as a distant, and a bit uglier, cousin to Diablo, aesthetically.
Soul Reaver strays further from the comparison, this time done to Ocarina of Time, but it still fits in. It lacks many of the features which add depth to OoT, but you stil get an similar action-adventure quest. Z-target-ish combats, an world that opens up for you to explore as you're given cool new abilities, the spectral-physical world duality (which can be compared to the young-adult timelines from OoT), the fast-travel portals (as opposed to ocarina tunes)... you'll probably only miss talking to random people, the inventory, the ruppees, riding a horse and fighting deadly chickens.

This Zelda-like gameplay turns out to be quite fun, as you use your bare hands, "spectral blade" or grab regular weapons from the scenery to fight the most peculiar kinds of vampires until they're prone to a finishing blow (any of the classic vampire-killing techniques, except using crosses and throwing garlic at them), and finally consume their souls (hence the title). There is also a very interesting use of the scenery with the spectral/material shifting mechanic. Some of the boss fights are pretty cool too, and they give you the new abilities I mentioned before.
The game counts with a pretty interesting storyline, which over the time has developed into its own mythologic lore. It is fueled by great voice acting by a cast of very talented actors. Heck, I could spend a day just watching footage from the recording sessions (which are included in the extra content from Soul Reaver 2 and Defiance if I'm not mistaken).
The soundtrack is nothing to write home about, but it does sound cool and work well within the game. It is mostly based on Information Society's "Ozar Midrashim 1.1" (undescribably amazing song, do check it out, right now, grab your headphones, crank'em to 11, please). In fact, the original song does play during the beautifully pre-rendered FMV intro, sans that weird intro about the huge holographic Ronald McDonald, obviously.
The graphics, although technically dated, are balanced with a fascinating visual identity of a decadent gothic world, painted by the alternating color palettes of the cold, dead spectral realm and the warmer physical one. If you have the chance, play the Dreamcast version, which looks better, in spite of that weird controller.

There are some minor drawbacks, though. You may find the long, unskippable and unsubtitled dialogues/monologues to be kind of boring at times, and they come through quite often. The combat tends to get stiffy and awkward once in a while, especially if you try to confront many enemies at the same time. The occasional platforming (hands-in-hands with the dated controls) can get annoying, as in most games of this era. Some of the block-pushing puzzles will annoy you. You may also get lost sometimes, as in not knowing where to go or what to do, so pay attention to what people(?) say to you in the game. Oh, and the game ends on a cliffhanger, but that's not such a big problem anymore, since you can get Soul Reaver 2 just as easily right now.

As for details about running this specific version of the game on my Windows 10 machine, check the comments.

On a closing note, I have huge respect for the Crystal Dynamics team and what they achieved here, while facing the budget and time constraints that were set upon them. And also how they managed to build such an universe out of pieces of different projects throughout the franchise so far (long story). Funnily enough, the cut content from this game kind of worked as the path to the making of its sequels.
Nowadays, many games seem to be influenced by this one (or share the same influences, at least). After this, I recommend you to play Darksiders and Batman: Arkham Asylum too if you haven't already. Shadow of Mordor is another one I can add to this list, because it is incredibly similar to a LoK spin-off, Dead Sun, that was cancelled around the time of SoM's release.
In a related fun fact, if you're not aware, most of this series has been written and directed by Amy Hennig, best known for her work in the Uncharted original trilogy.


Crystal Dynamics, please bring this back like you did to Tomb Raider.
That would be wonderful.

I don't know if there's much point in reviewing old classics but nowadays I try to sum up my thoughts on every game I play, so here we go. Maybe in the future, some videogame-rating AI algorithm will have use of it as input data.

First I'll note that this really is quite an old game by now (it came out in 1999, 17 years ago at the time of writing this). What you get on Steam is not some remake or even an HD remaster. This is a game exactly as it was back then, as far as I can tell. Personally, I had no major problems with it, running it through Wine, although I could only play in software rendering mode. I even was able to choose my native resolution of 2560x1600, though that didn't really change anything. Also, I could choose between 32 and 16-bit color depth which is just so sweetly old-fashioned.

"Old-fashioned" is something that is going to reverberate through your mind as you play this game. The intro cutscene is so simplistic it seems childish by today's standards. However much the games of today may be dumbed down, the quality of presentation and story-telling has definitely gone up. In many other respects, though, [i]Soul Reaver[/i] is very ambitious from a technical standpoint, in ways that impress even nowadays. The two main things you will notice are:

1. Level design — locations you visit are just huge, consisting usually of ancient structures that tower over you, and natural landscapes of majestic proportions. There are also no loading times as you traverse the areas, so you may visit a great canyon, then climb all the way up and from some weathered ruins look a hundred meters down at where you started. (This must be even more awesome when you're playing in hardware-accelerated mode...)

2. The spectral world — this is the dimension of the souls that is available to you, the Soul Reaver. It mirrors the material world but is only inhabited by demons and the spirits of the dead. The most amazing quality it possesses, though, is that it is crooked, twisted as if you were looking through a funhouse mirror. This change of geometry can happen in front of your eyes as you shift from one dimension to another.

[i]LoK: Soul Reaver[/i] really is a game that stands firmly between visionary and outdated — as well as awesome and flawed.

For instance, combat shows signs that it could be really visceral and gory. Vampires you fight are immortal so in order to annihilate them, you will have to throw them in water, fire or intense sunlight; impaling with a stake also works to immobilize them. That means that every encounter has an environmental factor — you will need to push the foe into an open fire or skewer them with a standing candelabra. But very soon you've tried all the different ways of finishing enemies off and combat becomes a nuisance rather than fun. And when you "die", you go back to the spectral world where you have to eat a couple souls to bring your health up, and then get back to the material dimension — rinse and repeat.

The whole game is actually like that, it consists of segments of contrasting quality. There's cool platforming and lame platforming (this is before more context-sensitive animations that you get with, say, [i]Assassin's Creed[/i], so one wrong step on that thin wooden beam and you just plummet down). Cool exploration and lame exploration (sometimes the structures you visit are extremely convoluted and hard to find your way around). Cool puzzles and lame puzzles...

Actually, this last one is the worst. While some of the puzzles are very original (the entire game is), most of the time you'll be stuck not because you don't know how to solve some particular conundrum but because you may not even know what the conundrum is, or what your goal is, or where you are, or where you need to go. Typically, when you get to a major new room, a short cutscene has the camera fly around, finally getting centered maybe on some door or something else. From then on you're on your own, with little or no further clues.

(Partly the reason for some confusion may be that the game was shipped in a hurry, and about 2/3 of planned features were cut. That left some empty spots where it seems like something should be etc.)

The state of having no clue is actually going to accompany you throughout your journey as Raziel. This game does not hold your hand. I mean, there are literally whole game mechanics that are optional and have to be discovered. Hidden areas you have to find yourself actually make a substantial part of the game. And what you're exploring is an open world, you can go anywhere, go back to any location... and there is no map.

So, would I recommend [i]Soul Reaver[/i]? If you're afraid of messing around with ancient games that may or may not work, then maybe you should wait for a remake or something. But if you're not, and if you like action-adventure games (this one reminded me somewhat of [i]Prince of Persia: Warrior Within[/i]), then it may be worth your time. It has a pretty cool fantasy story and is dripping with really awesome dark atmosphere. Took me about 19 hours to one-hundred-percent, although something like half of it was time I spent while being completely lost.

[b]The year is 1999.[/b] The series was a reasonably established and when we found out there was going to be a new one, everyone was excited to see Kain's progression as a vampire and his expertly written narration of an exciting new story.
And then the trailers were released. We are suddenly told that Kain is the antagonist of the game and that was truely puzzeling. It wasn't often that you saw the protagonist of the earlier games be the bad guy. But enough about [i]/back in the day/[/i] stories. Let's talk about the game.


[h1]THE STORY. Is it any good?[/h1]

The Legacy of Kain series has always had delicious, delicious narration throughout every game and this one is no different. It's a great way of giving exposition. Though sometimes they take control of your caracter for an unreasonable amount of time to vomit exposition down your throat, but at least it's all very well written.



[h1]THE GAMEPLAY. Does it hold up?[/h1]

This game was well made and rarely bugged out and had great mechanics and decent camera control. (In egoraptor's voice: for the time...) The thing is about third person games, they didn't have a clear idea of how to most efficiently program the controls, like most games at the time. And even so the camera sometimes get distracted with a wall or some shit that doesn't matter, it didn't really bother all that much for the most part because fighting had a lock on system and the geometry was mostly simple. And regaining health is just a matter of holding one button and sucking every cotton candy ball floating around all over the place (AKA Souls). [h1]-------CONCLUSION-------[/h1]

25526364.review:
Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is the second game in the Legacy of Kain series, changing up the formula from a top down hack and slash to a third person puzzle platformer with heavy Zelda influences. Taking place some fifteen thousand years after Blood Omen you play as Raziel, one of Kain’s lieutenants who started to evolve past the Kain and he did not like that. The plot can be summed up as Raziel growing wings, Kain being jelly that he did not have wings, then deciding to break said wings and toss Raziel into a water vortex to send him into a painful death… there is more to it than that but without spoiling anything that’s the gist of it. Raziel stays dead for about five hundred more years before the Elder God brings him back to life as a wraith because vampires have taken over the world and he’s not getting enough souls to reincarnate which causes the land to decay, so he needs a ‘Soul Reaver’ to help kill off some vampires and what better one to use then one who would have a reason to go to hell and back to kill the vampire lord Kain?

Overall the plot is solid, I enjoy the story and the feel of the gothic world they created and it stands the test of time, delivering great writing and voice acting which considering Amy Hennig of now Uncharted fame was the director, it is not a surprise. On top of that the graphics still somewhat hold up and for its time I am sure it was an amazing looking game. Now it has that PS1-era fabulous polygon look to it but even still I enjoyed the look of the game.

However that being said it is -very- hard for me to recommend this game in this day and age. Combat with vampires is horrible with repetitive button mashing and having to find a way to ‘kill’ the vampire, which means beating him up enough to toss him onto spikes or into sunlight and then eating the soul to make sure it doesn’t come back. Because of this I found myself in the later stages completely avoiding all combat as much as I could, only fighting off creatures in puzzle rooms. The puzzles are the second core part of the game, and for the most part they still hold up at being challenging while never being too frustrating, though near the end they start to feel like busywork as you do pretty much the same puzzle three or four times in a row, sliding blocks around to match up some picture on the floor being the major offender of this.

This all hinges on you knowing where you need to go however and the game does a bad job of telling you. It’s ambitious for its time to make this open world with a realm shifting mechanic allowing you to switch between a material and spectral world with the environment sometimes changing between the two, but when you are actually trying to get from point A to B and move the story along and the Elder God tells you its north of somewhere, you’re going to have a somewhat hard time figuring out just where he mean and how to get there.

The controls are straight up bad and at many times unresponsive, I found myself falling off ledges tiny ledges due to how fast you jump or how hard the gliding is to control and because of this the dungeons become a slog very quickly, when the game asks you to do lots of platforming you’ll want to tear your hair out and smash your keyboard when one little mess-up makes have to walk all the way back to where you were before. And the bosses… oh my how they are horrible. Pretty much all the bosses are puzzle bosses because you can’t really fight them directly, but once you figure out the puzzle they all become incredibly easy, breaking down to smashing a few windows or pulling a few switches at the right time.

Overall I can’t recommend this game. As much as I love the mood, tone, story, and characters, at the end of the day it is still a game you have to play and after about ten hours of tedious platforming and combat just to get an ending that gives you the middle finger and explains nearly nothing I was done. I can sum up the gameplay as ‘Off-brand Zelda’ in that you fight through dungeons, solve puzzles, fight a boss, and get a new power to help you out but it all just feels worse than how Zelda or other platformers of the same ilk do it.

That being said, the game has plenty of good sides - there's an entire set of spells that sort of act as a side-quest in that you will never run into them if you just follow the main mission. The platforming generally is solid (so long as the camera doesn't get in your way), and although the combat system has its issue (with enemies thrown onto the stabby bits necessary to pernanetly kill them often magically landing next to them rather than on them), its still rewarding in its own way - the fact that you usually fight no more than 2-3 enemies at a time shows that you're fighting against powerful vampires, not jut plain old mortals.

Not a bad port. Always loved this game, so I'm a bit biased. Take it from me, this series has one of the best stories in gaming period. Try it out if you like it I defy you not to play all of the others just to unravel the tale. Destiny, time travel, interdimensional conspiracies, vampires, and false gods this game is the best place to enter into the series. Between the voice acting and the writing this game is good enough, but Soul Reaver boasts the most enjoyable gameplay in the whole series.

The enemies and the environments work togather to create an interative playground for you to test out different and creative ways to clear out rooms. There are several ways to stun enemies from beating the hell out of them, to psychokenetic force balls to throwing rando crap at their faces. And once you've gotten them stunned they're your toys. You can grab them and throw them at hazars like spikes or flames, off cliffs or into the brimy deep. Impale them from afar or up close. It's just too much fun to experiment with.

While in the physical world if your health is brought down to zero, the world is transformed into the spectral realm. This changes the shape of the world and the enemies that spawn. Devour enough souls and you can return to the physical world die in the specral realm and you are transported back to the first room in the game. This would be frustrating if it werent for the fact that along your journey you discover way gates, and there is a gate right after the first room. So you rarely actually lose progress and through all of this there is nary a load screen.

All and all I've played the whole series and love each part for different reasons but this the the best in terms of the total package. If you haven't tried it yet start here.

18333962.review:
[h1]For more reviews and gameplay videos by Morgoth, check out my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198006568104/] Steam profile[/url], the [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCiwEA52JfjAgoF8uiB5k8gg] Youtube channel[/url], and the [url=twitch.tv/morgoth0221]Twitch channel[/url]!![/h1]

So this is the very first time I've ever played through any Legacy of Kain game, and after beating down Soul Reaver, I am overwhelmingly impressed.  Soul Reaver is an action/adventure/puzzle solving game in where you (Raziel), are harnessing a deep hatred for your former leader and pseudo-father figure, Kain, that runs so deep that an elder god decides to  utilize you as his weapon of destruction against Kain and his forces, as they have left the entire world in shambles from centuries of war and butchery.  So let's get down to it!

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]  Definitely one of the high points of this game (and there are many) is just the overall gameplay.  The controls might be a little loose, but the targeting and the executions are spot on.  And fun.  Like, suprisingly fun.  Nothing quite like taking a spear from a wall and impaling a demon/vampire creature straight through the abdomen, while absorbing it's soul afterwards for sustenance.  If this sounds like fun, definitely get this game because you will be doing this a lot.  Don't misunderstand though.  Incredibly, this game actually focuses more on puzzles rather than direct action.  Even boss fights are generally a small puzzle that needs to be solved, rather than directly assaulting the giant, horrific monstrosities (because let's face it, that immediately doesn't sound like a good idea as soon as you see any of the bosses).

Oh, and this game is not exactly easy.  Some of the platforming can be very difficult due to the loose controls, and the world does not exactly hold your hand.  It is very open-ended.  Very few hints are littered throughout the world to guide you on your way, but just enough is given to you if you really pay attention to what is being said.  In an age of games that practically play themselves, this particular type of difficulty in a game is a very welcome feeling.

The only slightly negative part of this game are the overwhelming amount of block puzzles.  Block puzzles.  Block puzzles.  BLOCK PUZZLES.  At any point in time through the game, it's a good bet that a block puzzle is within at least two rooms of where you are currently located.  They are interesting, but the developers really went all out with these puzzles.  None of them are too overwhelmingly difficult, but when they're in every room, it becomes mundane and repetitive.  

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]  Fantastic graphics for it's time.  Remember that this game did come out in 1999.  A mere three years after Super Mario 64.  There are a lot of clipping issues obviously for this particular period in time when this game was developed, but overall the game is pretty gorgeous.  Animations are very smooth, enemies are interesting, environments are gloomy and downright spooky, and bosses are horrendously disgusting looking.  Even for today's games, those bosses are the things of nightmares.

[h1]Sound:[/h1]  So the sound in this game is phenomenal, and probably the highlight of the entire game (at least it was for me).  Every movement makes a sound that is very adequate for what it is representing, but the sountrack that kicks in every once and a while is perfect for the theme of the game.  Dark, gothic, and eerie.  Partners perfect with what is happening on the screen at all times.  Especially the opening cutscene music, that also just happens to play near the end during a particularly important part of the game.  Oh, and the voice acting talent is, for lack of a better word, incredible.  Tony Jay is still severely missed.  The script is so well written that several games that are released these days, could learn a lot from sitting down and playing this game.

[h1]Lasting Appeal:[/h1]  So the total game took me about 12 hours to beat, and that's exploring a good amount of the world.  Didn't go for 100%, but pretty close.  Beyond reliving the adventure again, there is not too much reason to revisit this game after beating it.

16833802.review:
[h1]Soul Reaver [/h1]

"Tumbling, burning with white-hot fire, I plunged into the depths of the abyss. Unspeakable pain... relentless agony... time ceased to exist... only this torture... and a deepening hatred of the hypocrisy that damned me to this hell. An eternity passed, and my torment receded, bringing me back from the precipice of madness.  The descent had destroyed me... and yet I lived." ~Raziel

This game, to me, was the start of the Legacy of Kain series. Although, technically, that was actually Blood Omen. As a matter of fact, the first Blood Omen unknowingly set the stage and essentially serves as the backdrop for all of the Legacy of Kain games. In Soul Reaver however, you do not actually play as Kain. Instead, you play as one of his vampiric lieutenants, Raziel. But almost immediately, things immediately go bad as when Raziel approaches Kain and shows that he has evolved by gaining a set of wings (the first evolution of all of Kain's vampiric brood), Kain considers this a transgression against him. In an act of rage, he rips your wings from you, and then has you thrown into the Lake of the Dead. Burning, trapped in the abyss, Raziel reaches the bottom but he is lifeless, his body practically destroyed.

But centuries pass, and Raziel awakes, somehow still alive, but a twisted shell of who he once was. Then, as he looks around at his surroundings in the Abyss, an onimous voice booms: "Raziel, you are worthy." This being, only ever referred to as "the Elder God" in the Legacy of Kain games, claims that it is he who is responsible for your rebirth, or rather... your undeath. He calls you his Soul Reaver, and gives you the mission of hunting Kain down, for it is him that is responsible for the decay and ruin of the world, Nosgoth. But to reach Kain, Raziel will have to also hunt down and kill his vampiric brothers, long since corrupted while Raziel was away from the mortal world. Raziel himself had only just gained a set of wings before his execution, but his brothers... they had became monstrous to say the least.

This game, like all of the other games up until Nosgoth, are action adventure games. As this is a PC port of a game that is  sixteen or so years old, it's important to have reasonable expectations. For instance, some textures may flicker or not appear properly like they were meant to every once in a while. Controller support for this game is unfortunately borked, for when I tried to use my 360 controller, it appeared to work at first, but then Raziel would not stop moving at all. I at first recoiled in disgust and anger, using keyboard controls, but eventually became used to it and also remembered how much I still loved this game so it didn't matter to me after a while. Controller support does in fact apparently work for the other Legacy of Kain games, although, I can only confirm this for Soul Reaver 2 as that is the only other one I've started to play after finishing the first Soul Reaver. Personally, Soul Reaver 1 crashed for me about five or so times. But as you can save at any time while playing the game, I shrugged it off and considered it only a mild annoyance.

Yet, keyboard controls aside, I found combat as fun as it always had been in this game. As most of the enemies you face are vampiric in nature, simply knocking it down and shouting mean words isn't enough. Either pick up a weapon, impale, and then devour their soul, or beat them down a bit, grab them, and toss them either into water, a spike, or onto a fire. Combat becomes a simpler matter once you obtain the Wraith Blade, however, if you get hit and are no longer at full health, you lose it, forcing you to go back to the earlier methods. Another thing I always loved about this game is the bosses aren't "hit it until it's dead". A spider boss? Grab its eggs, set them on fire, and toss them back at them. A boss that is immune to water but not sunlight? Break some windows to let a little sunshine in and watch as it screams in agony. A certain boss near the end of the game that is invulnerable otherwise, you literally lure into a gigantic incinerator and burn him alive. There are only two specific boss fights that are... well, disappointing, and honestly, frustrating.

As you adventure through the wastelands of Nosgoth, as an undead vampire turned Soul Reaver, you have the ability to go between both the spirit world and the material one. As a matter of fact, if you run out of health in the material realm, you are forcibly sent back to the spirit world until you consume enough souls to regain your strength. Unfortunately, this does somewhat make there be little stakes in the game... as you can only receive an actual game over if you run out of HP in the spirit world. It makes bosses an easy matter as well. Get sent to the spirit realm, eat souls, find a portal, and try again until you win. Still, I always (and still do) thought that going in and out of the spirit world to bypass obstacles and solve puzzles was such a cool thing to do. I just love the visual effects it has on the world. It's not literally just the absolute same area but with a blue tint, no, these columns become shorter in the spirit world, allowing you to climb up them and then using a portal, you're back in the material world in an area that would have otherwise been inaccessible.

Eventually, when playing this game, it becomes second nature, but I'll just say it beforehand: "If you are in a spot and are seemingly stuck and it absolutely seems like a dead end, transfer over to the spirit realm."

Perhaps for me, the only truly infuriating aspect of the gameplay of the game is... well, block puzzles. I can't blame the game for having puzzles, no, but good god, if you actually explore the side areas, there are just so many block puzzles. There are other puzzles that are not block related but every time I ran into another one that did involve blocks I just... I hate block puzzles so much.

But in the end, I recommend this game (and series, as I wouldn't consider this a spoiler whatsoever, but Soul Reaver 1 ends by directly leading into Soul Reaver 2, so I don't know why you'd buy and play Soul Reaver 1 and then not buy and play Soul Reaver 2) not for its gameplay but... well, for everything else. The story, the music, the voice acting, the atmosphere. As long as you are able to appreciate an old game (and be willing to use keyboard controls) and move past the issues of... well, less than perfect PC ports, you'll probably enjoy this game/series.

So yes, even though I somewhat feared that the nostalgia I felt for this game was greater than the game itself, I was pleasantly surprised. It's not perfect of course, but it's very much worth playing.

One last thing to note, though. A couple of days ago, one of my friends actually recommended Nosgoth to me. I said I had it in my Steam library, and had been meaning to try it out because I loved the original Legacy of Kain series. He responded with: "What's Legacy of Kain?".

8/10.

13894946.review:
Legacy of Kain is a well known franchise amongst many oldschool players. Some were introduced to the series with Blood Omen, others began with Soul Reaver. While the core gameplay was different both of them shared rich story and nice voice acting. Soul Reaver is the second game in the franchise and is a direct sequel of Blood Omen.

The gameplay consists of exploration, battles with vampires, boss battles, platforming and puzzle solving. While I do like the franchise I also do not have bias due to nostalgia and do not like to see the game through pink glasses. Exploration is fairly nice, game offers interesting locations and architecture and there's a lot of backtracking and hidden secrets. Battles (at least at first) are interesting, but quickly start to get redundant and boring. While the game introduces a couple of new enemies the core battle mechanics stay the same, as you advance more through the game you get more power and enemies aren't a real threat, just an annoyance to stall you a bit. Boss battles are good, but short. They're not the "win by brute force" type of battles as you need to find a weak point / solution to defeat the boss. Platforming is fairly frustrating as the camera and controls are far from perfect. Nothing is impossible and can be mastered after trial and error, but jumping onto series of tiny ledges can be painful, especially if you fall down and are forced to redo the entire segment. Puzzle solving is fairly Tomb Raiderish, but also gets too repetitive: "Block puzzle A is introduced, now do it a couple of more times. Block puzzle B is introduced, now do it a couple of more times again.". The best part of the game (aside from story and voice acting) is the soundtrack. It's great and memorable, a lot of people know Soul Reaver's "Ozar Midrashim".

The PC port has flaws. It runs on newer systems, it's possible to run at 1080p and 60fps. However, it suffers from audio issues. The music has crackling noises, dialogue skips. The only solution is to play it in software, texture unfiltered mode. Another flaw is that the hardware mode goes up to 1080p, while software mode goes up to 2160p. Makes sense, right? When compared to PS version the soundtrack is pre-recorded. It has less tracks and doesn't really change according to what's happening around you.

Should you get this version of the game? That's up to you. If you can oversee no texture filtering then go for it. If you prefer better overall experience, but lower framerates then go for the PS version. Dreamcast is supposed to be the best version.

13860316.review:
(Ignore my time on record as I've spent most of my playtime offline)

Easily one of my most favorite games of all time! I remember playing this on the original Playstation like it was only yesterday. In my mind this game set the bar very high for what video games were capable of. Wonderfully written script and rich dialogue, Extremely clever puzzles that make you consider all possibilities. A unique and large open world game that managed to pull off one of the first concepts of streaming data directly from the disk, cutting out loading screens from area to area. Crystal Dynamics had outdone themselves when making this game, and it's a shame that we don't get games like this more often.

By today's standards this game would be considered a little rough around the edges (remember, this is 1999 we're talking about), but if you can look past its dated graphics and very rare glitches you will find a well crafted story with unique characters, all of whom are well rounded and are even pursuing their own goals.

Following the noble vampire Raziel, now turned undead wraith, on his journey to seek revenge for the betrayal of his creator Kain, you will find that the world they inhabit is dark and desolate, but not without reason. As their destinies unravel, you soon realize that there is more at stake than just Raziel's personal vengeance. 

The Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is heavy on storytelling and puzzle solving, but the combat isn't the best (in fact the combat is terrible). Many of the puzzles are far from obvious. Some are on such a large scale that you may have to visit several areas just to solve one and move on, but they are definitely rewarding as the further you go the more you learn of kain's actions, Raziel's resolve, and this dark, slowly dying world and how it came to be the way it is.

I have tried this on several computers and can easily say it runs quite well on modern machines. It runs on essentially any resolution, although I'd recommend playing at 4:3 resolution as that is what this game was made for. Widescreen works, but the game stretches. If it doesn't run well on yours then there may be a complication or something affecting its performance. 

There is a problem with the audio, however. Sometimes the audio suffers from problems and you may miss some dialogue and key ambiant effects without realizing it, but it's easy to figure out as you can identify it when the sound starts to get choppy or, say, when you jump and the grunting noises you normally hear are missing. It's an easy fix, simply quit and restart. Now I know some people might find this a daunting task, and all I can do is assure you that this game is well worth the time and patience.

When I saw this game on steam, I was a little apprehensive to play it at first, as I was afraid my nostalgia would cloud the fact that this may be a terrible game after all. But once I ran it, I fell in love with it all over again. It can stand on it's own merits, and comes from a time where people were more worried about clever storytelling and breaking new ground than trying to introduce exclusive features and new DLC packs to increase product longevity. It's a masterpiece from another era, and shows that video games can be more than the generic "Action Adventure" label that is used to describe them.

I [b]wholeheartedly[/b] recommend this game and any other in the Legacy of Kain series.

I have been a fan of Legacy of Kain series but never did play this game when I was a child because the game was too simply too dark for me but the whole lore of the series has intrigued me in the longest time (my dad played this game and was immediately hooked as am I).

I played this game after playing Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain for the PC(Why didn't they have this on Steam?) and like Blood Omen, the story is clearly superior to other games of its time, having a superior voice acting talent in this game with a proper direction of the story to boot. The characters in this game are pretty likable in telling the story of the game, the character you play, Raziel, often tells you, time to time, his views of the current world he is in, in a pretty elaborate and amusing way during his journey. I have to say the character development regarding him is well done once you are done with the game. This game's story takes you far into the future, centuries after Blood Omen. There are few references from Blood Omen that are mentioned in the game, I'd say it's not that important to play Blood Omen, but it's clearly recommended for future references in the other games.

The gameplay seems fresh for a PSOne/PC(1999) title, 3D Platforming is a notable element of the game, jumping around the place feels very organic in a way that it paved way for future 3D action/adventure to takes notes on basic things such as climbing using the ledge to reach another platform. Gliding feels pretty organic too because of the big and high places you will venture to, it proved useful in Raziel's journey. 

This game also has puzzles for you to uncover while most of them are cube puzzle where you have position the cube like objects to its correct positions, although it feels pretty ridiculous as God of War's Kratos doing the same thing(and Thank golly, it was this game that started this element of gameplay), it felt pretty fun and I had the feeling I have to finish it right away, but I can't help that I'm thinking that Raziel would be better off as a "Plumber" of sorts, he certainly has a great talent for it, *snicker*.

The fighting system feels that it contributed a lot to upcoming games such as Devil May Cry, Dark Souls and other action/adventure games that have a feature for you to lock on the enemy in close combat while holding a button. While holding the "autoface" button, you automatically focus on your current adversary and anticipate his move. While in this state you anticipate his upcoming attack and dodge with the proper directional button and the jump button. This would lead the enemy to be in the open, off-guarded. It's a simple mechanic that does its job well in the starting stages but as you progress, you uncover more skills you can abuse to your enemies such as things from side quests.

Side Quests in the game does make the game a little easier but it is no easy task to uncover them blindly though. The side quests contain powerups that would increase your health, your magic and your arsenal such as glyph spells. The game would be little more of a challenge if you play without the powerups, but just a little because of one little thing.

This game setting has you going into different realms time to time in real time. I'd say it's an impressive feature back in the day, because the 3d setting changes/transforms IN REAL TIME as you change from one realm to another and it is needed for you to do in order to progress more into the story.

The enemy designs are pretty grotesque and scary, it is what repelled me from playing it as a kid. I think third boss and its minions takes the cake that will keep preventing me from getting a sleep for a day, two or three if I was dealing with this game back then. The sounds are fit the setting but the ambience of the setting puts me on edge especially when the game decide to bugs regarding the sound such as sound loops and what not, you know I just have to reset and load the game from where I was. Voice acting is top notch, it is dramatic but it does its job pretty well for a video game of its age.

This game has certain bugs/glitches such as game crashing suddenly during lengthy play times in a sitting, enemies going T-Stance on you all of the sudden, sound loops that are pretty scary and nerve wrecking. They are pretty minor and not necessarily would break the game render unplayable.  Just save consistently, you can save anywhere. I MEAN IT.

12697634.review:
[b]PROS:[/b]
+ awesomely amazing story
+ cool game soundtrack
+ great voice acting
+ original concept (for both story & gameplay)
+ challenging combat
+ boss fights
+ two realms - physical and spectral
+ puzzles
+ atmosphere of Nosgoth

[b]CONS:[/b]
- clunky and outdated graphics
- occassional audio glitches
- controls are difficult (but customizable at least)
- open ending hinting to Soul Reaver 2
- can have compatibility problems on some PCs

[b]Comment:[/b]
I will be honest to you from the start - I am biased towards this game. It has been a fundamental pillar in my gaming life, it was one of the first PC games I played and I love it. Just look at my avatar - it's Raziel. First time playing it was way back in 2002 but I have fond memories of how awesome this game was. Yes, I can see the flaws it has today, it did not age that well ... but please hear me out. Soul Reaver is a game that was revolutionary in it's time. It combines combat and puzzles in the big post-apocalyptic world of Nosgoth. Both are difficult so if you like more casual games I guess this one is not for you. The game does not take your hand, you have to try stuff out for yourself. And die a lot in the process. But not really die since this game created a great mechanic of shifting between physical and spectral realm. So if you die in the physical world you shift to the spectral one. If you die in the spectral world you reset at the Elder God. You can however shift when you want and this gives the game it's dynamic feeling. Boss fights feel very satisfying when you finish them. You also get a power from each boss you beat, adding extra layer of gameplay each time. All of this was fun, but the story and narrative is why I LOVE this game! The story telling is what this game nailed - from the writing to the voice acting. Plus it has a really cool soundtrack as well. Some downsides are here as well, the game is old so graphics and compatibility are not that great, though it worked fine on my Win7 laptop. The open ending can also be annoying for some people, although it is not that bad (and continues well in SR2). And I could write all day about this game but I will stop right here because you already know if you want it or not from what you have read. I will end this review and give one of the most true and heartfelt recommendations I ever gave on Steam!

10481610.review:
This game is really fantastic. It combines puzzles with a pretty nice fighting system and one hell of a cool story to top it all off. If any of you have played the original release on PS1 you already know this game hasn't been named one of the best games on PS1 without a reason.

However this port is quite unsatisfactionary to say the least. It plays just like on PS1, it looks good and I had no problem with setting up my controler to work with it (be sure to not only change the configuration of the controler in game but also to select it to be the prefered method of playing from the pause menu in order to make it work) but there is one huge problem. It crashes randomly. I have tried multiple different resolution settings but either way it crashes every now and then.

I have managed to get only about 4 crashes throughout the whole game but at the very end of the game, there are a lot of cutscenes and I had to replay all of them at least 5 times to get past them. It would always crash. Finally, I decided to check for integrity of the game cache (which is an option that can be found when you right click the game in your library and then go to properities) and it found 2 corrupted files. Guees what? One of them was my save file and it got deleted. Right before the last boss fight. All in all, I have managed to find a save file at this exact point on the internet and I have finished the game but I am still quite dissapointed that Crystal Dynamics have done nothing about this problem.

To sum it all up - If you like adventure games with good combat system, original story, puzzles and a big world to explore (with a lot of secrets to find, optionally) then this game is definitely for you. Even after over a decade this game still feels right and puts a lot of newer titles to shame. If you don't want to deal with multiple crashes though, you're probably better off buying the original PS1 version and playing it on some sort of emulator.

Oh and if you're wondering about gameplay time, it takes about 16-17 hours to complete if you decide to find most of the glyphs and some of the health upgrades but it should take even up to 30 hours (or more?) if you decide to find every upgrade and all of the glyphs. It might also vary a lot depending on how well you solve puzzles. It sometimes takes long time to figure out what to do. I used a guide only twice but I suppose it was much more rewarding to not use it more.

La saga Legacy oof kain, es una saga de juegos reconocida por su gran historia y buen diseño de personajes, ademas de ser la primera serie de videojuegos donde te tienes que jugar TODOS los juegos para entender la historia. Sufre un poco en el gameplay un poco fuera de epoca...pero lo recomendaria a este juego con TODO el paquete.

Despite its age, and the poor graphics by today's standards that comes with such age, Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver, and truly the entire Legacy of Kain series in general, still remains my very favorite video game of all time. The game's story is marvelously  well written, leaving you wanting to know at all times what happens next, what's around that corner, and what kind of environments you will discover. This game hits it out of the park with not only its well-written story, but its phenomenal audio work too. The soundtrack is absolutely superb, and one of the best video game soundtracks out there. The voice acting is amazing, featuring some big name voice actors, including Tony Jay - famous for Judge Claude Frollo in Disney's The Hunchback of Notre Dame - Simon Templeman, my personal favorite voice actor - famous for many roles, including Gabriel Roman in the Uncharted Series - and many more. Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver was developed by Crystal Dynamics (famous for the Gex series and Tomb Raider series) and published by Eidos Interactive. The lead director for the game was Amy Hennig, who later went on to co-direct the Uncharted Series. Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is filled to the absolute brim with secrets and hidden rewards, and I highly encourage those of you who purchase this masterpiece of a game to explore them all.

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver, and the entire series in general, is a true masterpiece of gaming. Its graphics may be rather dated by today's standards, but they're rather good for the standards of when it was released in 1999. The true art of this game is not in the graphics, but rather the storyline itself as you follow the fallen Vampire lieutenant Raziel avenge himself and uncover the dark truths of the hypocracy he sought to destroy. With twists and turns around nearly every corner of this exquisite work, you will be highly entertained and likely will want the other games to complete the story. I do warn you however that the storyline can get very complex, but I feel as if that merely adds to some of its charm and beauty.

9132373.review:
Don't let that low playtime deceive you; I've spent more time in Soul Reaver on the console than I'd care to mention.

This game has an absolutely riveting, Gothic story narrated by some of the BEST voice actors to ever grace the field (RIP Tony Jay), solid gameplay, decent block puzzles, and more secret content than you can shake a stick at.

Speaking of the secret content... Dear GOD is there a lot of it! It is possible to complete the game, start to finish, and only experience about 40% of the entire game! There are so many glyphs, eldritch energy pickups, and life coil extension pickups that you can get lost in just collecting the miscellanious crap!

Combat can be hit-or-miss (moreso on the PC than the console because of the movement controls), but overall it feels visceral and satisfying; there is something disturbingly cathartic about beating a vampire about the head and neck area before tossing him bodily onto the nearest pointy bit of architecture.

However, I WILL admit that this game has not aged well graphically. At all. The opening movie aside (which shames current-gen consoles TO THIS DAY I might add), everything is hilariously blocky, even by late-90's standards, and it was one of those games where no one had a moving mouth texture.... Origami graphics aside, the game is a source of nostalgic eyecandy from the Dreamcast/PSX-era gamers on here; you can thank Soul Reaver for pioneering continuous-streaming, open-world games like GTAV.

TL;DR
Pros
+engaging, well-delivered story
+Visceral, satisfying combat
+Mind-bendingly horrific boss battles that lend a sense of power to their participants
+Epic traversal and mobility mechanics
+A large, fairly-open world full of rich, well-written lore
+Tony Jay, Michael Bell, Simon Templeman and Anna Gunn all in the same game

Cons
-This game has NOT aged well
-You can tell a lot was cut out of the game before release
-PC controls handle like a technologically-advanced turd
-Low replay value except for story
-Major audio glitch (rare as it is) can wreck enjoyment quickly

I wouldn't recommend buying this but that's not to say it's without it's merits - the writing and voice-acting in particular have been greatly praised and from the very beginning these make the game easy to love, especially if you are a fan of high fantasy and dictionary use. However, equally noticeable are the inadequacies of the game engine in realizing the ambition the devs had regarding "the bits in between cutscenes", or "gameplay" as it is otherwise described.

The first, and perhaps most irritating problem is that this is at heart a console game, and the port is BAD. The controls are, by default, WASD for movement and the arrow keys for actions. That's right - NO MOUSE. I know this is an old game, but it's a real shame that including support for one of the most basic faculties of a PC wasn't considered a priority, it couldn't have been too difficult to implement considering how much better the game would be for intuitive camera controls.  Without them establishing even a basic awareness of your surroundings can take around half a minute of slowly shuffling around and resetting the camera, which makes even simple tasks extremely fiddly and only accentuates further problems.

Secondly, the combat. I can see what the devs were trying to do but it comes out too clunky and situationally a nightmare in the hands of some poorly designed environments. The combat is based off some novel principles - most of the games enemies are undead, and as such require more killing than usual, most encounters will involve incapacitating enemies before destroying their body, with the use of fire, water, sunlight or simply impaling them. This is an interesting mechanic but quickly becomes at best a chore and at worst extremely frustrating. 
The worst example I can provide is when the player is required to enter a room which contains 3 aggressive enemies but no environmental means of finishing them off, by this time the player has access to a weapon which can incapacitate and finish enemies, while remaining available at all times - but only when the player has full health, as a result, taking even a single hit will remove the player's only means of winning the fight and will require the player to retreat to heal before trying again, this would perhaps be a "fun challenge" if the combat possessed any depth, but the lack of any means of blocking or countering enemy attacks makes this an almost impossible task, requiring either luck or to get enemies stuck in the terrain - there is only one attack type (which I might add, is assigned to the same key as USE, have fun bashing doors), this gives the player basically no options regarding combat and allows no means of skill to assist in most encounters. (BTW the example takes place in a room with a multi-level block puzzle. Also the enemies respawn occasionally. FunFunFun.)

Like I said, the story is excellent, but if that's all you're there for then you might as well just watch a silent playthrough on youtube, which I actually do recommend.
But as far as playing the game yourself is an option, I'd say don't bother.

TL;DR -- Gameplay sux, v. dated, bad port but great story, voice acting & visual design.

Playing as Nosgoth´s most wanted vampire wraith, Raziel, we got a game which almost seemed impossible to make within the PlayStation constraints. Detailed graphics, seamless loading of areas, shifting between realms, excellent atmosphere and music in a vast, decaying world. These are the reasons that SR1 became a classic which everybody  who played it at release remembers to this date. How can anybody forget the iconic intro where Kain rips off Raziel´s wings in a dramatic fashion? The dialogue and interesting story pulls you into the world right from the start. Even if the cutscenes are not the shortest, the flowery dialogue is a joy to listen to when delivered with such profoundness and heart. This is accompanied by an amazing atmospheric soundtrack by Kurt Harland whose eerie compositions are great to listen to even 20 years later. He designed a layer system based on variations triggered by certain conditions being fulfilled and it dynamically changes in according to what is happening on screen. As Raziel shifts between the realms, the soundtrack changes as well. Creatures´ cries become more twisted and warped.

However, it is the game´s core mechanics which make it such a good game. You start off weak, thrown into the realm of the dead and your ever present guide in form of a voice leds you to a portal which brings you back to the living. While indestructible, Raziel will still fall back into the spectral realm if he is damaged too much in the real world. Time stands still in the spectral realm which is useful in certain puzzles. To regain his former strength Raziel needs to consume the souls of his enemies and in epic confrontations, the souls of his former brothers. Those grant distinct powers - phase through gates, climbing, telekinesis and swimming - and thus open vast possibilities on exploration. Entirely new areas open at some point, sometimes leading to a secret spell which you wouldn´t be able to acquire otherwise. These glyphs are useful but not required to finish the game. Raziel can also collect health upgrades over the course of the game which adds a reason to explore every nook and cranny. Warp gates are great for this as each time the game is turned on, you always start in the bottom of the Abyss but a nearby gate can transport you around whole of Nosgoth.

Exploration on its own is not enough and when traversing, Raziel must fight his now newly devolved kin. You only start with your claws but soon find out that using torches and spears is important to finish the vampires off as their wounds heal fast. The culmination of exploring different vampire clan territories is a meet up with one of Raziel´s brothers, now monstrously deformed. Due to their sheer size conventional weapons are not enough to bring them down and you have to retort to using the environment against them. With each lieutenant´s soul, Raziel gains stronger and new paths open. One of the upgrades is the legendary Soul Reaver, which attaches itself mysteriously to Raziel as his permanent weapon. It can only be used when Raziel´s health is full but once manifested, it will sustain Raziel indefinitely and two strikes are enough to send any enemy into a vulnerable state.

Unfortunately, the game slightly suffered in the end as many areas, abilities and events have been cut to make the deadline. Even though it ends on an infamous cliffhanger, it gave us Soul Reaver 2 and Defiance. This amazing series is far from forgotten but it is sad to see this port being subpar in comparison to the later entries. The dynamic soundtrack has been completely removed from this version, replaced with pre-recorded tracks. It actually reacts to Raziel being close to an enemy, in boss battle or just simple indoors or outdoors, something not so common back in the PlayStation days. The game is also locked to 30fps which is possible to unlock with fan tools but this shouldn´t have been the case. There are other frequent issues such as sound effects endlessly looping which happens a lot more often in the pc version. Dreamcast version which came out in 2001 has 60fps and higher polygon models of all main characters and enemies. It is sad that they didn´t port this version instead. For an optimal experience, get Dreamcast or even PS1 version.

973593.review:
The second game in the Legacy of Kain series, Soul Reaver follows the bad ending of Legacy of Kain: Blood Omen, where Kain, a former nobleman turned into a vampire to take revenge on his murderers, took part in the events that involved restoring the world's balance. Stepping aside from its vampiric roots, Soul Reaver ventures into a demonic area, telling the story of Raziel, one of Kain's "first-born" vampire leutenants who was thrown into the Abyss for daring to evolve prior to his own master, only to be awaken centuries later by The Elder God in a spectral realm.
On his quest to avenge his death Raziel must solve a lot of environmental puzzles that involve switching between material and spectral realms in real time. Enemy encounters are quite rare, but the fights look stylish thanks to many various ways you can finish your opponents using either weapons or the environment.
Controls are somewhat awkward and require some time to get used to. Being released in 1999, the game looks amazing even today. The world of Nosgoth is huge and seamless, you will never see a single loading screen here. Voice actors do an impressive job reading through beautifully written dialogues, which makes the complete lack of subtitles even more disappointing.
Soul Reaver is simply one of the best action-adventure games of its time. If you missed it during the PSOne era now is a good chance to join Raziel in his atmospheric journey through life and death.

1093054.review:
Legacy of Kain Soul Reaver is the sequel to Blood Omen, and my god did it ramp things up quite a lot.

The plot is, after the main character of the last game conquered the world. He kills you and throws you into an abyss. After that your corpse is resurrected and you have to traverse a dead world you helped destroy inorder to kill your murderer.

The game is focused on puzzles moreso then combat, due to the fact you actually cannot die. The player instead shifts between the lightless and weightless dimension of the dead to the material realm. This is very important for specific puzzles and sidequests. The game takes place in a semi-open world with no loading screens. 

Another big part of Soul Reaver is just how many sidequests there are. Just running through the game will land the character with no health upgrades and no special glyph powers. Should the player return to prior areas you can find new things that you didn't see previously.

However there are some minor flaws.The game ends on a cliffhanger that leads directly into Soul Reaver 2. There is also an entire website devoted to all the content that was cut prior to release.

The other important aspect of this game is it's port. SR1's PC port is flawed in a few ways. Much of the soundtrack doesn't play at specific moments, and this reduces the quality of the game in a lot of unfortunate ways. It remains a bit of buyer beware in that regard.
